text:
I have never rated a recipe before, simply as all the recipes that I try from the site are fantastic, and much smarter cooks than I always give great feedback.  However, one tip on this recipe was SO helpful--Linda Mc advised to put the popcorn in the pan to warm in the oven before adding the brown sugar mixture, and that was the KEY.  The first batch (with cold popcorn) was a disaster, but with the warm popcorn in the roasting pan already, the mixing was a breeze and the batch was fantastic!  Thanks to everyone for all the tips that are so helpful!

text:
Yummy!  I reduced the butter to 1/2 lb like others suggested - perfect.  I used a 12 quart stainless steel All-clad stockpot to pop kernels, make the caramel, and coat the popcorn (the pot was covered in oil from popping the corn and the caramel didn't stick - w/plenty of room to stir).  Note: there is no way you would ever find me mixing this in my sink - impeccably clean as it is, the thought is repulsive to me! (no offense to anyone who thinks this is acceptable).

Anyway, I poured the coated popcorn onto 2 silpat lined sheet pans (was fresh out of nonstick foil).  I only baked one of the sheet pans because the kids begged me to let them keep eating the other one.  For softer/chewy/shiny version, don't bake.  For firm/crispy/non-shiny version, bake, but reduce baking time to 45 min.  I used tongs to break up clumps while baking and cooling.  We loved both versions.  

Hints:  
1.  Reduce butter in half.
2.  Use a good quality, heavy pot.
3.  If possible, avoid microwave popcorn.
4.  Remove unpopped kernels before coating.
5.  Keep popcorn warm in 250 oven until  ready to coat.
6.  Stir with a silicone spatula.
7.  For softer/chewy/shiny version, don't bake.  For firm/crispy/non-shiny version, bake, but reduce time to 45 min.
8.  And most importantly, if you mix this in your sink, don't give any to me! :)

text:
I am rating this recipe again because I was eating so much of this popcorn, its wonderful, that when I saw the review from the person who cut the butter to 1/2 cup I had to try it before I gained 50 pounds.  Understand I HATE to change something this good, afraid it won't be the same, but I have to say I can not tell the difference.  I kept everything the same but only used a half cup butter. PERFECT!! I use 3 bags ACT II Old Fashioned Natural microwave popcorn.  I have used more expensive popcorn but this works the best. Also, one thing I have learned after making so much of this popcorn is use a name brand brown sugar.  I picked up a store brand once because thats all they had and the coating came out grainny. Now with half the butter I'll probably just eat more. YIKES!!!

text:
I've been making this same recipe for years, but I do it in the microwave.  You put the popped corn in a paper grocery bag.  Then you microwave the butter, sugar, vanilla, and corn syrup, letting it boil for one minute.  Then stir the baking soda into the caramel mixture.  Pour it  over the corn in the bag and shake it up.  Microwave the whole bag for about 30 seconds and shake it up again.  Spread it out on a lined baking sheet to cool down.  Tastes absolutely incredible, and done in under 10 minutes.

text:
This recipe is the same one (minus the vanilla) my mother has been using for 20 years.

There is another way to cook this - use the microwave.  After mixing the popcorn and caramel, divide the corn into two paper grocery bags.  Microwave each bag for 30 - 40 seconds, remove the bag from the microwave and shake it.  Repeat microwaving and shaking for a total of 4 times for each bag.  Open the bags carefully and spread out the corn to cool - breaking up any large pieces. Clean up is easy - just throw away the bags.

text:
I've been making this recipe for years and it is always a favorite for both young and old. It tastes better than anything you can buy in the store.

Here are my hints:
  
1.  always use "golden" brown sugar, not the dark brown which is likely to burn.
2.  bake it in a very large turkey roasting pan.  It will all fit and still be easy to stir.
3.  clean-up is very easy, just soak the pans for a minute in hot soapy water.  All the hard candy just melts away.
4.  Always buy double the ingredients(you'll be making it again the next day!)

5.  If there is any left over, store in an air tight container or it will get soft.

Make it once and it will be on your top 10 list too!

I was a little worried about what kind and how much popcorn to use when I saw this recipe.  Do I use plain or butter? 2 bags? 3 bags? 4?  I ended up using 3 bags butter popcorn, popped in the microwave.  Picked out the kernels and cooked the rest on my jelly roll pan.  DELICIOUS!  I baked for about 40 minutes.  Next time I'll bake it for the full hour because it was a little too sticky to enjoy without picking at my teeth the whole time and the think the extra 20 minutes will help harden it a little more.  Also, next time I'll try plain popcorn b/c the butter seemed a little heavy.  Still, it was wonderfull and we ate the whole bag in only 2 days.  Thank you!

text:
HELPFUL TIPS NOT MENTIONED: I was doubtful about this recipe but let me tell you that my husband's soldiers went bonkers over something that was SO QUICK to make! If you have trouble mixing in the caramel that I do recommend just dumping it on top instead of trying to keep a thin stream ...just stick it in the oven for a few minutes for it to get hot again & then you can finish mixing! :)  As mentioned, the caramel will become foamy so don't worry, and do not try adding the vanilla PRIOR to taking it off the oven!  I use two disposable foil pans for turkeys side by side in the oven.  Always have one in the oven while mixing the other! Use enough butter so the caramel doesn't get too sticky (1/2C). I used 3 bags of buttered popcorn (brand REALLY isn't important), and I also don't find using cheap no-brand brown sugar to be a problem.  Really!  I've used all kinds of combinations of nuts and prefer macadamian and/or almonds.  I like using 2 pans b/c it gives you room to stir comfortably.  Be sure when you take out the pan to stir to get the bottom REAL well or you'll have one solid layer of caramel on the bottom.  Also, be sure to let this cool before breaking as directed in the recipe but stir one last time when you take it out of the oven.  You must put this back in the oven when the caramel begins to stiffen up b/c continuing to stir at this point is pointless as it breaks pieces of popcorn. Store in giant ziplock bag at room temp!

text:
We love this recipe and have made it for years.  For my mother, who loved Cracker Jacks, I'd substitute 1/4 c. molasses for part of the corn syrup. I spray a large disposible foil "turkey" pan w/butter-flavored Pam and put the popped corn in.  Place the popcorn in the 250 degree oven to warm for 5 min while the syrup boils. (It's a little easier to stir syrup into popcorn if it's warm and the pan is big ).  You can leave caramel corn in roasting pan to cool if you gently stir once or twice while cooling. The Pam makes the roasting pan easy to clean, and a hot, soapy soak takes care of the caramel pot.  I keep the large foil pan tucked into a plastic bag in the closet so it's always available, two of them, as a matter of fact, since we always double the recipe.

text:
I have made it a couple times now.  The first time was to fill X-mas tins as simple party gifts for the holidays, and now I made it to bring to a summer picnic/barbecue as a snack.  It's extremely easy to make, but can be a little time consuming, especially if you're making more than one batch at a time.  Here are a few things I've found to be helpful:  1. I have used both butter and margarine, and both turned out great.  2. I have used both light and dark corn syrup, and both turned out the same, but the dark syrup gives it a little more color.  3. I used large, heavy duty cookie sheets to bake it on, and had no problems.   4. I would recommend spraying your pans with cooking spray and if you want an easy clean-up line them with parchment paper.  5. If you want some of the caramel corn to stick together, make a little extra caramel mixture and drizzle it over the top of popcorn after mixing and placing on baking pans  6. If you are a fan of Poppycock/Fiddle Faddle popcorn, you can add 2 cups of your favorite nuts (almonds, pecans, or peanuts work best).  If you make the recipe with nuts, I recommend increasing your caramel mixture to 1 1/4 cups butter, 2 1/2 cups brown sugar, 2/3 cup corn syrup, and 1 1/4 teaspoons vanilla

Fantastic recipe! But I can't look at a cup of butter and wonder if it could be reduced a bit and yield the same results, so the first time I tried it with 2/3 C. butter and it was perfect.  Next time I got a bit bolder and used only a half a cup of butter and it was perfect again!! It tastes the same and is light and crispy just like the original, maybe not quite as rich, but who cares when you just cut the fat by half!!  Also, the second time I didn't have the corn syrup at home so I used pancake syrup, you can't tell.  Great recipe!

text:
Very Yummy, it's the same recipe I use for Puffed Wheat Squares as well, minus the baking soda.

I too use only 1/2 a cup of butter (margarine squares are fine if you have it on hand and no butter but don't use soft margarine)

TIP: 1/2 cup unpopped popcorn = 4 quarts popped so for those who had other measurements I thought this would help.
I basically pour the 1/2 cup then overpour slightly. 
This is ONLY true for FRESH popcorn (check the packaged date) if it is older/dryer it will make smaller, tougher popped corn and so you should use more.

2nd TIP: DO NOT stir candy while it is boiling, it is a rule of candy... for those who experienced grainy texture this is why.

Temperature and time affect how candy performs which is true for the initial boiling and the baking of the corn afterwards. Find what you like and make a note for yourself. Less time boiling = chewier candy, more = harder.

Enjoy!

text:
There is already a lot of great advice on here, but I’ll add my two cents. First LUV this recipe!  It’s especially great around the holidays.  I’ve even been asked if I bought it at a specialty store when I gave this popcorn to guest.  Now my tips for making the popcorn:  1. I use microwave popcorn find a brand that is “natural” – but be careful that it doesn’t have butter or salt added. 2. I pop the corn while the caramel is on the stove, this cuts down on the cook time and as a bonus the popcorn is warm when you pour the sauce on (when you use three bags, pop one bag before you start then the last two while you cook the sauce). 3. Make sure you don’t just dump the bag in the tray, keep unpopped kernels out. *3.  I get a disposable turkey pan from the dollar store – NO MESSY clean up! 4. ***This is real important*** after you take the popcorn out of the oven keep stirring it!!!!! Otherwise it clumps together. It usually takes 5-10 mins to cool; I’ll stir it 3-4 times in that period to insure that I don’t end up with a few big clumps of popcorn, that then have to be crumpled into ugly bits.

text:
I make this every year for Christmas and put in the big popcorn tins everyone ends up collecting.  I give them to friends and family and they don't get any the next year unless they return the tin.  I use a large Rubbermaid tub to put the popcorn in and fill it about 1/2 to 3/4 full and I also make the syrup mixture in the microwave in a large 4-cup measuring cup.  I melt the butter, syrup and brown sugar for 3 min. and then add the baking soda (and vanilla- which I don't use) and then it's in for another minute.  When you pour it over the popcorn all you have to do is shake the big tub until all the popcorn is coated - works great and not messy at all.  I also use the aluminum turkey roasting pans and I store all of my "equipment" in a big trash bag in the basement when not using.

text:
this recipe is fantastic. its simple, and delicious. better than the carmel popcorn you purchase. a couple HELPFUL suggestions : do NOT use dark brown sugar. must be light. ALSO - i found the BEST. EASIEST. CLEANEST way to do the final step ( pouring caramel over the popcorn) is to not use a large bowl - USE a brown paper bag ( brown grocery bag) and double bag it. coat ENTIRE inside with pam or any kind of cooking/butter spray. while caramel is boiling, put half of your popcorn in the bag. when the caramel is done, simply pour half of it over the popcorn in the bag. then, quickly add the left over other half of popcorn to bag, and pour remaining caramel over that. squeeze top of bag closed and shake vigorously and in all different directions, to evenly coat popcorn with the caramel! This method honestly works fantasticly and cuts your clean up time in 1/2. No sticky dried caramel bowls or spoons to clean! just throw bag out after pouring caramel popcorn onto oven trays.   :) hope this brings some peace and ease to a few! happy holidays .   ALSO- for a smaller batch - i recalculated serving size to 10 , and with this i used a bag and a half of popcorn. worked out perfectly. even just one bag of popcorn would be fabulous, just a teeny bit thicker coat of caramel on top.

text:
I had trouble with this recipe.  The caramel always came out granulated and the taste wasn't quite right.  I adjusted it and now it is PERFECT.  I made the following modifications: 1/2 tsp. salt, 3/4 cup corn syrup, and 1 tsp. baking soda.  The measurement for unpopped kernals equals 2 cups before popping.  TIP:  If you put the popped popcorn in a paper grocery bag and cut a small hole in one corner, you can shake out the unpopped kernals (because you definitely don't want "old maids" in your caramel corn).  WARNING:  You really need to use a large saucepan for the caramel mixture, because once you add the baking soda, the mixture foams up and increases volume considerably.  That could be messy!  I put the popped popcorn in a roasting pan and pour the caramel over top.  Mix well with a spatula and bake at 200F for 1 hour without stirring. YUM!

text:
Excellent recipe!  A trick for keeping the unpopped kernels out...put a cookie cooling rack on top of your bowl of popcorn, flip it over and shake the kernels out.  I also put half of the cooled caramel popcorn in a large bowl and coat with melted white chocolate, lay it out on waxed paper to cool.  Then toss with the remaining caramel corn. Yummy!

OMG! This stuff is so addictive! Way better than any caramel corn I've purchased. And really easy. I made my own popcorn. I figured out that 10 Tbsp. unpopped kernels = 5 quarts popped corn. Which is 1/2 C. + 2 Tbsp of kernels and used 3 tbsp. oil to pop corn in - perfect! text:
Tastes so good, I cant believe how easy this was to make!  I didn't have corn syrup, so I used honey instead and this worked well for me.    A helpful tip: rather than drizzle the caramel over the popcorn, I made the caramel in a giant pot and dumped the popcorn into that pot instead and coated the popcorn in there.  That way the caramel is still warm and manages to coat all the popcorn easily.  I was able to coat twice the amount of popcorn with the same amount of caramel syrup this way.

text:
I have a TNT recipe for caramel corn, but needed a big batch so I chose this one instead, as sometimes doubling candy recipes can be disastrous. It's greasy when fresh, but after a few hours, is perfect! You need two VERY large bowls to mix this up, unless you have one gigantic heatproof container. Be sure to remove any unpopped kernels before mixing, and because you put two large baking sheets in the oven at the same time, rotate the pans as you bake, to prevent the bottoms from burning. Also be sure to line the pans with foil. A little more than 1/2 a cup of kernels yielded 5 quarts of popped corn for me.

text:
I worked in a popcorn shop for 3 years. This is very similar to our recipe, except we popped our popcorn the old fashioned way. This receipe works better with buttered microwave popcorn if you like the buttery flavor that is essential to the caramel taste. If you substitute, margarine for butter, then use buttered popcorn. The other secret to good caramel popcorn, other than name brand, Dixie sugar, is the vanilla, use pure vanilla, not extract and if you have access to vanilla from Mexico or the Caribbean island, this is the best. I've been making this recipe for 8 years. Still love it!!!

text:
I scaled this recipe down to half. I use 7 - 8 cups of popped corn. Here's the trick: spread popcorn onto a large lightly greased baking pan. Place in 250 degree oven to keep warm while you make the caramel syrup. Drizzle caramel syrup holding the ladle or spoon up high to get the thin stream. Carefully toss to coat then stir every 10 to 15 minutes; for me this only takes 30 to 45 minutes..comes out perfect every time! Thanks for posting this recipe!!

text:
It was super easy! I used one cup of unpopped popcorn and it was the  perfect amount for the candy part of the recipe.  There's a tip to cleaning the pot, just boil some water and you'll have a pot that has no more sugar in it. Also someone mentioned about graniness, make sure the candy mixture is fully incorporated and if there are any sugar left undissolved it can recreate sugar crystals and make it crystalize again. Hope that helps! THanks for the recipe! Edit: The popcorn lasts a week covered in an airtight container. I've also made it with some homemade salted nuts and the sweet and salty combo is yummy!

text:
This is the best caramel corn recipe in the world. The ratings don't lie!  Everyone loves it at Bunco and at parties. For a twist I melt some semi sweet chocolate chips, between 3/4 of a cup to 1 1/2 cups, depending on how much popcorn I want to cover, and toss some of the the baked, COOLED caramel corn with the chocolate until evenly covered. Spread out on a covered tray to cool. I store the chocolate covered corn in a seperate zip lock and then mix in with the plain caramel corn when I am ready to serve it.  I like half chocolate covered and half plain but I love chocolate. A ratio of 1/4 chocolate to 3/4 plain is similar to Harry & David's Moose Mix but it tastes even better.

it must be simple

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe. If  you want to make it even easier as I aways do, you can make the whole thing in the microwave. Put your butter, sugar and corn suryp in a large bowel and micro it until it boils. Once it starts to boil set the timer for 3 min. Then add your baking powder. Have your popped corn in a large brown paper bag. Pour the caramel mixture over the popped corn. Close the bag and shake well. Then with the bag still folded over, place the whole thing back in the microwave for 3 min. shaking once half way through. When the 3 min is up give once last good shake and lay the corn out on wax paper to cool. I think this is much easier than the oven way and turns out just as yummy. It also is harder to burn this way.

text:
SO GOOD – it melts in your mouth!  I have made this many times over the last six years!  It is just down right yummy!  I use two regular size bags of microwave popcorn making sure to fish out any un-popped kernels, and I always add deluxe mixed nuts.  I strongly suggest you use a larger saucepan than you think you’ll need, because once you add the vanilla and baking soda it will really bubble up and that stuff is HOT!!  I have found a 3-quart saucepan works perfectly.  I bake mine in two large disposable aluminum turkey roasting pans that I spray with Pam.  That gives me plenty of room to stir during the baking process.  The caramel sinks to the bottom so it is important when stirring to lift and scoop it up over the top of the popcorn so it becomes evenly coated.  I also find that in my oven I need to bake this a little longer to get it nice and crispy.  To be sure check a piece or two to check for crispiness.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent recipe.  I love caramel corn from Garrett's in Chicago but it is so expensive, I wanted to try and make it at home.  My family agrees this is very close.  Follow the recipe exactly, use jelly roll pans, non-stick aluminum to cover the pans (a great tip from previous reviewers), AND a silicon spatula to do all your stirring.  It is highly heat-resistant and naturally non-stick.  BE SURE TO STIR WELL every 15 minutes as the recipe calls.  It is critical.  My first batch did not turn out as well as the second because I did not stir thoroughly.  Also, do not use too much of the syrup - use just enough to coat thoroughly but not where it is dripping off the popcorn and depending on your oven you may not need to bake the popcorn the whole hour.  Baking too long even by just a few minutes will cause it to scorch.  Hope these tips help!  It is really delicious!

I have made the Amish Friends Caramel Popcorn recipe for the last couple years. It was O.k. I came across this one and tried it. IT WAS THE BEST OF THE BEST! I don't know if it is the butter vs margerine because otherwise the recipe is the basically the same besides that and the amount of popcorn used.  I made over 100 cups of this to give as Xmas Gifts. A HIT! I was getting phone calls left and right with compliments. I would suggest using 1 stick of unsalted butter and 1 stick of regular butter. I used 2 1/2 bags of Microwave Light Popcorn and sprayed a brown paper grocery bag for tossing this. I would also recommend cooking it for only 45 min. stirring every 15. Otherwise it could taste burnt a bit. And lastly I drizzled mine with white and dark chocolate! GREAT!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe. I have some tips that will perhaps help somewhat.
1. I use a nonstick to prevent the sugar from burning during it's 4 minute boil time.
2. Work quickly to prevent the caramel from hardening up too quickly before you've had a chance to spread it around on the popcorn.
3. After taking the popcorn out of the oven, break the popcorn up on a wax or parchment sheet BEFORE it hardens.
4. Try using butter flavored popcorn for an interesting, more buttery flavor.
5. Try adding nuts, such as honey roasted peanuts, salted peanuts, pecans, use your imagination!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
CARAMEL PUFFCORN!!!!!
This recipe deserves more than 5 stars, but that's all the higher they go! I did change one thing with it, I used PUFFCORN instead of popcorn. You can find this at any grocery store in by the bagged chips. I used the 7 oz. bag (which according to the nutritional value readings is 21 cups) and scaled the recipe for 20 servings, PERFECT!!! This is a great tasting caramel for either regular popcorn or the puffcorn, I just prefer the puffcorn, it's lighter and has a "melting" effect in your mouth Try it just once, you'll be hooked on puffcorn! The recipe is very easy to follow and not time consuming at all. Some other reviews stated it took too long, set your timer on your oven to go off every 10-15 minutes and go stir, that's pretty easy to me! It may seem like it takes a long time to those mouth watering children gazing into the oven though! It's well worth the wait though!

None
text:
This is a terrific recipe.  I've found that using a turkey roasting pan works best as it can hold all of the popcorn at once.  Use a plastic spatula to stir the popcorn during baking as the caramel does not stick as much to it as a metal or wooden spoon.  I used half the butter and even though the caramel was frothy and did not pour easily, it spread evenly enough during the mixing.  My husband was impressed by it!  Thanks for the recipe!

I have made this recipe now for several months...I was having trouble with the mixture sugaring after being in the oven for the hour, but I read somewhere's that if you use name brand brown sugar (such as C & H) I wouldn't have that problem... so I tried it and it's been working ever since!  So use name brand brown sugar for a much better outcome!

text:
Caramel popcorn is one of my very favorite treats, so I make it pretty frequently.  Since I found this recipe, it's been the only one I've used!  Sometimes I don't even bake the popcorn after it's mixed with the caramel (I can't wait an hour to eat it!!) - I throw it in the microwave for a couple minutes then let it sit a couple more to get slightly crunchy.  I've had no problems scaling this down to about 1/4 the recipe, which my husband and I can handle in a matter of minutes.  :-)

This doesn't taste anything like the stuff you get in the big tins at Christmas - it's a million times better.  This is quite addictive! text:
I made this for Xmas and it was a big hit - everyone said it was better than cracker jack.  I added in some peanuts too.  This is an easy recipe but it was kind of a pain to have to stir it every 15 mins within the 1 hour baking timeframe.  It is also very important to make sure the pan that you use is greased very well b/c after the popcorn cools off, it gets very sticky and it's hard to break it up if most of it is stuck to the pan. However, it was easy and I plan on making this again in the near future!

text:
This recipe is amazing! I made it to give as gifts for Christmas ... super easy and inexpensive, and everyone loved it. I made it a few times, tweaking it a bit every time and here's how I liked it best. Always at least double the recipe ... it will go fast! I nearly doubled the amount of popcorn I used, I don't like each kernel to be completely covered, a light coating is perfect. I halved the butter and it turned out just fine with plenty of buttery taste. To mix the popcorn and caramel, I used a huge stock pot coated with crisco (to keep it from sticking) and then poured into the baking dishes before putting in the oven.  Once out of the oven, turn the popcorn out onto wax paper to cool. Once cool, drizzle with dark and white chocolate. Enjoy! I'll never have to try another caramel popcorn recipe again!

text:
I absolutely love this corn!! I doubled the reicpe since I knew it was going to be a hit. I used the tip of keeping the popcorn warm since it helps with not setting up the caramel until fully mixed. Definitley butter the sheet pan or bowl before mixing the corn and caramel on it, or even putting the popcorn on it if using a bowl to mix. It will help when stirring later since the caramel won't stick to the pan. I suggest using two people to mix since time is of the essence. I do like the buttery flavor of using the full cup. When it came time to measure my Karo syrup, I substituted 1/4 of it with maple syrup. It adds a nice depth. This is my first review. I know it's kind of out of order for a recipe, but I hope it helps everyone.

text:
This recipe is perfect as listed! Delicious, sweet and buttery but not too rich. I use 3 bags of microwave Orville Redenbacher plain popcorn. I bought a huge, deep aluminum disposable pan (the biggest one they have for catering chafing dishes) and pour the popcorn on one side and pick out all the unpopped or half popped kernels as they hurt and do so with each bag of popcorn. Then I follow the recipe as directed- I could not imagine trying to stir on 2 cookie sheets. Everything cleans up well and I store the pan in my pantry. Easy, simple and lasts several days in an airtight container or Ziplock bag with the air removed. Everyone raves over it!

text:
Well, I was silly enough to think that we'd still have enough popcorn even if I halved the recipe, since it's just me and my husband. We ate all of it in just one day! Needless to say, we will never be buying store-bought caramel popcorn again. Make sure the pot you are using is big enough for the caramel sauce, as it will nearly double in size as it is boiling for the 4 minutes. Don't be worried about getting all the popcorn pieces coated all at once, because the caramel will melt and distribute over the pieces during baking/stirring. I baked mine for 45 minutes as per previous reviews and the popcorn was perfectly crunchy. I also added peanuts, but I'm curious to find out if there is a good way to make the peanuts stick to the popcorn.

text:
Fantastic, easy recipe. I only baked it 30 minutes and that was enough to dry it out. I adjusted the recipe for 2 quarts for a little snack and it was plenty for 3 people to munch on. I didn't bake it in a pyrex, instead I baked it on a sheet pan with a silpat. I also buttered my bowl for mixing. After I pour the caramel out I fill the saucepan with water and put it back on the burner for a while. The hot water will dissolve the sugar and make for an easy clean up. I also dip my spoons in there to clean and pour the hot water over the remaining dirty dishes in the sink. Some things to add in would be salted peanuts and pretzles.

country:
None
text:
This recipe is incredible.  I don't know how people can give any bad reviews, especially when most of the time they don't even follow the recipe. They just make it up as they go along and it turns out bad, then blame the original recipe.   My suggestion is to keep the popcorn warm in the oven while making the caramel, it mixes up easier and the caramel won't harden so quickly. When boiling the caramel make sure to time it for four minutes starting as soon as it starts to bubble or it will be over cooked. Make sure to take it off the heat before adding in the vanilla and baking soda.  In some ovens 1 hour is too long and you end up with a bitter burnt sugar taste.  30 min is good in my oven. It comes out crunchy and delicious.

I did use margarine instead of butter without any problems.  I also used 1/2 cup of unpopped corn in my air popper and found the candy coated it well without making a mess. text:
Unbelievable!  This is delicious and easy to make.  I was always kind of intimidated by the thought of making caramel corn.  It seemed way too hard, but it's not at all with this recipe. I read that some people used microwave popcorn, I used air-popped and it turned out awesome. My only advice is to spray everything with non-stick spray, especially the pan you boil everything in, if you don't it is going to be so hard to clean.
**Don't forget the salt, I forgot it in one batch and it makes a huge difference**

text:
This recipe is great! I've made it twice in a week and gave half to my parents and kept the other half for my husband and I and it hasn't lasted more than two days in either house! I followed some other reviewer's advice and cut the butter amount in half. I also kept the tempature at 200 and baked it for an hour, stiring it every 15 mins. It is a little difficult to get the brown sugar mixture to spread over the popcorn evenly, but be patient, it's totally worth it. The popcorn breaks apart very easily after baking it. Easy clean up too... I used a disposable tin turkey pan and it worked well.

text:
This was the best caramel popcorn I have ever tasted - even better than the expensive gourmet popcorn. I simply followed the directions, except that I only baked it 45 minutes. Clean up was simple: I used 17" long jelly roll pans and lined them with parchment paper. The caramel did not stick at all when I went to turn it, and at the end, I just crumpled up the parchment and threw it out. I will be making this a lot, but as the other raters warned, it's addictive! I think I'm also going to try coating it using a paper bag instead of using two bowls.

country:
None
text:
Excellent! I wish I had made this prior to reading the last few reviews--do NOT dump your bag of popcorn into your mixing vessel, or you will have lots of unpopped kernels--a VERY bad thing. I used 50% dark/50% light brown sugar and a low butter popcorn (2 bags was just right). The prior suggestion of using tongs is a great one! I mixed in a paper grocery bag and baked on foil-lined & sprayed cookie sheets, so clean-up was minimal. I will however, not cook it as long next time (maybe only 30 mins @ 200). In the latter part of cooking, the caramel started to melt off the popcorn. The pooling made the final product less attractive.

text:
This carmel popcorn is a HIT! I served it at a party, one person that claims up and down he "hates" popcorn, loved it! I also made it for my fall wedding, we put it in fall patterned "goodie bags" as favors. My one comment is to make sure you use shallow enough pans when baking so you cook evenly, and to be careful using Caphlon. I used 2 "lasagna" sized pans, one a cheapy kind, and one my caphlon, and the caphlon pan BURNED the carmel on the bottom of the pan and i could not stir in the burned carmel at the bottom as it would all taste burnt.  VERY GOOD, a little messy to make, i always end up with carmel corn stuck to my socks after making this in my kitchen (kind of hard to stir "cleanly", some usually ends up on my floor!).

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Okay, first off, USE A CANDY THERMOMETER! Be careful not to have your heat too high, and slowly bring to hard crack stage (300 deg F). If you use a 6 qt or so TEFLON stock pot, you will have plenty of room for the sugar sauce, once it expands from the soda, and it won't stick. Have your popcorn (1c unpopped) ready in a large roasting pan that you have sprayed with Pam, and as soon as your sugar is ready, pour over your corn and stir with a Teflon spatula or spoonula. Transfer to a disposable aluminum roasting pan; I lined mine with parchment to make stirring easier. Temperature and time are accurate.
I had no problems with burning or sticking at any point, mine came out pleasantly crispy but not hard. Only 4 stars, because no candy thermometer temp provided.

None
text:
I have been making this recipe for about 40 years.  I got it from a 'farm cookbook'.  If you are tired of picking hulls out of your teeth, try making it with OkeDoke popcorn puffs from the grocery snack isle.  It is wonderful.  NO hulls!  Also, I find that if I put the puffs in the oven BEFORE I start the syrup, it makes it easier to coat the popcorn/puffs if they are hot.  I pour it right out onto my clean countertop as soon as it comes out of the oven and it is easier to break up. Every year I use it for gifts for many and they all look forward to it.  I made 2 batches yesterday and guess I will be making at least 2 more.  I always get requests for the recipe.  You do need to get it in a container soon after it is cooled or it will get sticky if it is in the open for very long.  We love it in Michigan! I used to use margarine but some companies have changed their formula so now I use strictly BUTTER!  After all, its the holidays and we treat ourselves with things we don't normally have.

text:
Fantastic and very easy recipe.  I use two large bowls for stirring the popcorn.  Be sure to cook the caramel on a medium heat or it will burn.  I have made this recipe 5 times in two months, I have sent three batches with my husband to work (at a ski resort, in the vehicle maintenance shop), it is gone in less than an hour.  
This recipe also makes a good caramel sauce for ice cream or deserts, just cook for 2 minutes, not 4 minutes.
Thank you for this recipe!

I followed the recipe instructions to a T - with no modifications.  The results were exceptional.  The popcorn was so buttery, crunchy, and light that it melted in my mouth.  This recipe was a little messy to make, even with careful hands and a VERY large bowl, but water dissolves caramel, so my dishes cleaned right up with minimal elbow grease.  Elsewhere, the caramel hardened and was easy to "break off" of surfaces like the stove and countertops.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum! Really loved the way this turned out, and clean up was not that bad. A few words of advice that I gathered:
1. I used just 1/2 cup butter. (all I had) It wasn't greasy, and still made enough caramel to coat popcorn. If you want them super coated, you may need to adjust your caramel:popcorn ratio.
2. I used 3 bags of microwave popcorn (no butter)
3. Remove unpopped kernals before coating. Put in bowl 1, shake a little, and move to bowl 2. Kernals will remain in bowl 1. 
4. I don't have a turkey roaster, so I just lined my largest cookie sheet with two strips of aluminium foil, with a slight overlap down the center. The excess over the sides make it very easy to stir all of the popcorn during the baking cycle. (foil cools instantly when pulled out of the oven, making it easy to handle.)

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Here's a couple things I wish others had told me before making this recipe! 1) The sugar - the darker it is the more it burns. 2) I thought I had too much popcorn & too little coating but when you add the baking soda it doubles like crazy... I ended up having too much coating & not enough popcorn! Keep this in mind. 3) Try not to use dark roasting pans as they burn the sugar faster. I had 2 batches & the darker pan almost burnt my popcorn.  All in all, good recipe. Will be making it again :) Thanks to other viewers for their hints.

text:
Phenomenal. Always a huge hit! Probably one of the most complimented recipes I make. I tend to use a few more cups of popped popcorn, so it thins out the coating a little bit (and stretches it further, so there is more to eat). Also, I use a wooden spoon to mix. For cleanup-I just let everything soak in water and dissolve until a simple wipedown is all that's needed. No need to struggle and scrub.

text:
Awesome recipe.  I used my old large oval turkey roaster.  I took about 1 tablespoon of the butter and melted it in the roaster in the oven and added about 1 1/2 cups pecan halves and toasted them while the carmel was cooking.  I added the still warm microwave popcorn and stirred in the sauce.  After removing from the oven and cooling it for a few minutes I threw in some candy corn for a festive touch.  Everyone at our trick or treat gathering requested take home bags to eat more later.

None
text:
As soon as the weather starts to turn in the Fall I start thinking about this recipe!  You need a REALLY BIG bowl to hold this much popcorn so definitely follow the advice of the reviewer who suggested using a turkey roasting pan. Once the popcorn is coated you can transfer to baking pans or just bake it right in the roasting pan.  This worked really well for me.  Watch it closely towards the end of the cooking time because you may want to pull it out before the full hour unless you want it very crunchy.  There's no substitute for homemade caramel corn.  Great Halloween snack.

text:
WOW!!  I made this yesterday and it is as good as all the reviews say!  I read through quite a few of them to get some tips.  I popped my popcorn on the stove, and I kept it warm in the oven(that was the best tip of all, it make the caramel spread out much easier).  I used a large aluminum rectangle roasting pan sprayed with Pam.  When it was cooling I gently shook the pan a few times until it was completely cooled.  I am going to use this for my son's class' halloween treats for school this year.  I am also going to make up Christmas tins for my family and friends.  Nest time I am going to try using half the buter to see if there is a difference.  Thanks for the great recipe that I will be using for years to come!!

text:
Great recipe! This works great with 2 bags microwave popcorn. Hints for easier clean up: foil wrap the two pans and spray with Pam. Pour the popcorn directly into the pans, pour half the sauce over each and mix right in the baking pan. Wash the sauce pan IMMEDIATELY before the caramel hardens. Oh so good!

text:
This was an excellent recipe.  I had been making one caramel corn recipe from a friend but it never got as crunchy as I like it, maybe because it had cream of tartar - who knows.

Anyway - this was great.  The only modification that I added was to use a bit more salt.  I couldn't taste any salt when it was done so I sprinkled a little over it all.

A good idea that I came up with was to open a paper grocery bag and lay it on my counter.  I took the warm caramel corn and spread it out on the bag and used a spatula on it's side to break up all the pieces.

Thanks Brian.

text:
Fabulous and extremely easy!  I prefer my caramel corn to be extra coated with buttery caramel and found that this recipe is perfect for exactly 2 standard bags of micro popcorn.  I end up coating one bag at a time with this recipe and it comes out perfect! ***TIP: use TONGS to toss and cost the popcorn while baking in the oven. After the 45 min in the oven, I spread out the caramel corn on a cookie sheet to cool and allows the caramel to harden just a bit.  Thanks Brian...it's true - this tastes just like Chicago's famous Garett's popcorn found downtown!  :)

text:
I was looking for a caramel popcorn recipe before Christmas to try out. This recipe was a lucky find! I followed the recipe as written and thought it turned out great. As written it does have a heavy butter flavor, but I liked that. I then cut the butter in half like several reviewers mentioned and it still turned out great. In fact I made a few batches over the holidays and gave it out as gifts. You do need the full hour in the oven as the stirring helps obtain even coating and it sets very crunchy and not chewy/sticky.

country:

text:
I am making this right now! I have been making this recipe for years and had no idea where it was from.  It is the biggest hit every Christmas when I make it.  My only other suggestion is to buy the big aluminum roasting pans from the grocery store (they are a few bucks) and use that to stir and bake your corn.  It is non stick and lots of room and so easy to clean!  Plus they are reusable I have been using the same 2 pans for years now! Also, make sure to use a larger sauce pan for the sauce as when you add the baking soda it will double in size, kinda fun actually ;-)  and yes pull out your old maids!  Enjoy! PS I also add salted peanuts to the mix yum!

text:
I have been making my own custom version of caramel popcorn for years and my wife never likes it.  I decided to spend the extra and try this version, and boy am I happy I did.  The popcorn was crispy and not sticky like mine usually came out.  And fortunately or UN-fortunately my wife loves it too.  She says it taste like cracker jacks, which has me planning to add peanuts next time to give it the true Cracker Jack Flavor.  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
I never waited for caramel corn before; I always ate it warm and chewy---  made by someone else.  The anticipation was killer and I admit there was lots of melty, sweet nibbling. Other than lack of self-control, I sure would have liked a line that reminded me to clean out the duds, but hey, I can pretend they are really hard peanuts.  I think the "secret" has to do with when you stop stirring and when you take it off the burner. The mixing and waiting is tedious but I think the results (after cooling) were top notch. (except for the duds)

text:
Fantastic.  Everyone always wants me to bring this to Christmas parties.  The secret really is to keep the popcorn and pans warm so the caramel won't cool too fast and make it impossible to mix into the corn.  I use disposable metal pans so lots less cleanup. I made it once without the soda and vanilla and it was still great.

text:
Wow! I blew my diet on this recipe! We had a big bag of Boy Scout Popcorn, and I was looking for some special way to fix it when I found this recipe. It is wonderful, delicious, and addicting. This would make a great and inexpensive bake sale item. Also, there are several ways to kick it up a notch, not that it needs it! The next time I make it, I may drizzle melted chocolate over it after it is done baking. Honey Roasted Peanuts would make a nice addition as well. My daughter suggested using melted peanut butter chips as a drizzle.                                                                I should mention that I was almost out of butter, so I used half butter and half light butter. Simply amazing!

text:
This recipe is the exact same as my family one minus the baking soda....I googled why one would need it and it states that it keeps it softer so it doesn:t dry rock hard or be so gooey it sticks to your teeth bad.  I made this recipe to a t and it turned out waaaay better than the one my family uses I even called up my aunt to tell her.  TIP after cooking time  place on parchment paper then you dont end up with clumps.

text:
I had very easy prep for this, I popped porcorn and measured and placed it into my large stainless extra deep lasagna/roasting pan which I had sprayed with non-stick spray.  Kept the popcorn warm in the oven as some had suggested.  Made the caramel mixture, poured and stirred to coat directly in the roasting pan.  Then baked as stated for one hour!  Surprisingly easy!  Clean up was super easy, just soaked the pot and pan for a few minutes!

i must say, following the cooking instructions is very important. once i finished (baking as well) it turned out soooooo delicious!!! i couldn't stop eating it. my kids wouldn't leave the table until they were able to get some. the baking scared me a bit because it looked like it was boiling over (that is where the stiring comes in). it tastes great baked and not baked (its really chewy) my only problem is the grease at the bottom of the pans. i just dabbed the excess off with paper towels. other than that, it is a HUGE HIT!!! my oldest wants to add peanuts, marshmallows and chocolate chips. i think its fine as is. the next time i make it i will only use 1/2 cup butter like someone posted to see if there is a difference. i would suggest using 3/4 or 1 cup of unpopped popcorn kernels. i had more caramel than expected. its still good!!!!!

text:
Helpful tips from other reviewers made this really easy.  I used 3 bags of microwave popcorn.  Make sure you dump the popcorn in a bowl so the unpopped kernels fall to the bottom of the bowl.  I put everything in a paper grocery bag and stirred and shook the bag and put back in the microwave for about 30 seconds to warm it so the carmel coats well.  You may need to microwave a couple of times to make sure it coats well.  Then I pour it out on freezer paper until it hardens.  It was a hit when I made for my kids classmates at school!

text:
This recipe must be very forgiving because I really botched it up and the popcorn is still incredibly delicious.  This is the kind of food that you eat, and eat, and keep eating until you look down and realize that you've eaten the entire bowl.  I only made 1/2 batch, and wish I had made more since it really wasn't that difficult.  Finding a big enough bowl to fit all of the popcorn is the hardest thing about this recipe.  My first "mess up" was that I only had 1/3 cup butter, instead of 1/2 cup, but it still tastes buttery, and I almost think that the full amount would have been too much.  After finishing coating the popcorn, I realized that I never added the baking soda - mess up #2.  And my 3rd wasn't really a mess up - I just decided based on some reviews and how my caramel corn tasted and hardened that I didn't need to bake it.  I would probably opt to skip this step in the future.  This stuff doesn't even compare to the store bought.  This is buttery, sweet, a little salty.  It's crunchy, a little chewy - it's everything you want in caramel corn!

text:
Best caramel corn ever.  Reminds of going to the fair as a child and getting a big cup of warm caramel corn and eating it with a spoon.  I reduced the butter to 1/2 cup.  Other than that I followed the recipe exactly.  I mixed the popcorn and caramel in a large paper bag to reduce on dishes.  Worked like a charm.  I also kept the popped corn warm in the oven at 250 until it was time to mix with the caramel.  I baked it in the oven as stated but found out its actually not necessary.  The amount I left out to eat warm hardened perfectly on its own.  Next time I will skip the baking altogether.  Thank you for such an easy and wonderful recipe.  My 5 children went gaga over it!  I'm going to have to make more tonight if we're going to make it through the weekend!  Superb!

Yum!  I am on my third batch.  I halved the butter as many suggested. I used Orville Redenbacher's Natural Simply Salted microwave popcorn and kept it warm in the oven until time to coat. OMG!!!  This recipe should come with a warning label that reads highly addictive!  It is so easy and it tastes so much better than any you can buy.  Like others suggested, I used only 1/2 cup butter and it was plenty.  I popped two bags of the 94% Fat Free Microwave popcorn(that is all I had on hand) and I also used Safeway brand brown sugar.  I was afraid when I took it out of the oven and it was sticky.  I baked it in two 9"x13" glass dishes sprayed with Pam.  When I took it out of the oven after the hour was up, I spread it out on a jelly roll pan and kind of separated it a bit while it was warm.  After it cooled, it was perfect!  Just make sure you stir it up every 15 minutes like the recipe says.  Next time, I am going to add peanuts or almonds.  This would be great to give away at the holidays.  Thank you so much for sharing this delicious recipe!

text:
This is so good it should be illegal! The secret is keeping the popcorn hot. I think that's what keeps it from deflating when you put on the caramel. Also the stirring during the baking time,that seems to be essential. I use wooden spoons for the mixing and stirring and I grease everything. I've made this twice now and both times it has come out just melt in your mouth perfect. I have the sweet and salty thing going on so I up the salt some. I roast fresh peanuts to put in and I also use air popped corn. In my air popper,which has it's own half cup measure, I use two half cup measures, that's two batches,half cup at a time, and then another quarter measure and that has given me the correct amount of popped corn. I keep the corn hot in the 250 oven and just follow the recipe from there. I have cut the butter in half and it's just as good really. I thought I'd only make half a recipe this time but for some reason ended up making the whole thing, stuff really is addictive! lol

This recipe makes really, really good caramel corn!  I used smart pop microwave popcorn, as it was all I had on hand.  I took others advice and kept the popcorn warm until ready to mix.  It mixed very easily and coated extremely well.  I found it helpful to take to popcorn out of the pan while it was still hot and place it on parchment paper to cool and get crunchy!.  That way none sticks to the pan.  After about 10-15 minutes I was able to break up the popcorn easily.  Very good!

text:
Awsome popcorn. The best I have ever had I made it into Cinnabon Clone Caramel Popcorn: Use the recipe as stated but with twice the popcorn and 1/2 the butter. Make the frosted coating: Melt 6 cubes of white bark in small non-stick sauce pan set on low. When melted stir in 2 tsp ground cinnamon. After popcorn is removed from the oven/cooled/and broken apart, place wax paper on counter with popcorn spread out in a single layer. Frost with melted bark using a wooden skewer or chop stick, dipping into pan and shaking over popcorn. let dry and enjoy

I really like this but it came out on the grainy side.  I'm not sure why, but I have made this several times with margarine and have not had that happen.  It still tastes good, but would prefer it smooth.  Also, with butter, you get a more toffe flavor and with margarine you get a true caramel flavor.  I always cook caramel corn in a large, disposable roasting pan to make it easier to stir without having pieces spill out.  Very good either way!

Fantastic!!!! This is so addictive and delicious! I added a couple of sprinkles of cinnamon to the caramel mixture. I have made this recipe a number of times - I usually make it with 1 cup of earth's balance margarine that has non-hydrogenated fat. text:
This was so delicious but I did have one tiny issue with it.  After it was done, the caramel looked very grainy and clumpy on the popcorn, not a smooth shiny coat like store bought caramel popcorn.  You didn't really notice the grainy-ness when eating it because of the crunch of the popcorn, but still, I was a little embarassed sending it to work with my hubby because it looks like it didn't turn out right...  I don't know if this is normal for homemade and noone minded it or if maybe I just needed to boil mine longer than the 4 mins... Hmmm...  Well I will definately try this recipe again and hope for better results, because it was so yummy!

text:
Easy to make; tastes yummy - actually, it's quite addicting!
**update; i've made this several times and my only suggestions are: 1. use a large tablespoon of coconut oil (it's solid and found in health food section) when popping the corn, it gives it a bakery style taste - noticed only after the caramel topping is added; also...1 heaping table spoon of coconut oil to 1 cup of un-popped kernals (the mushroom style of popcorn kernels makes nice big popped corn) seems about right
2. use a NON-STICK pan when cooking the caramel topping; HUGE difference in texture/taste; THE BEST!!

text:
I've been making this caramel popcorn for years, only I cook the caramel for 5 minutes and I omit the salt.  I use one cup of popping corn which I then air-pop. This is delicious and addictive.  I like to use a silicone mat on my baking pan, but waxed paper coated with cooking spray works okay (just be careful not to tear it) and makes clean-up a breeze. I tried using half the butter as some suggested; it tasted the same but it didn't make as much caramel, ended up with some pieces of naked popcorn.

3 bags of microwave popcorn- natural (not butter flavor, otherwise its too greasy)

text:
This popcorn tasted really great. I also added melted bark chocolate to the popcorn after it had cooled. Once the chocolate hardened, the popcorn was ready to serve and be devoured! I took it to a party and people raved about it. Cutting the butter in half makes the caramel very hard to mix with the popcorn, but it'll spread throughout in the oven when you mix it. Definitely be sure to mix every 10 minutes, otherwise the popcorn will stick to the pan and the caramel wont mix evenly with the popcorn. It tasted great and am definitely going to make the chocolate-covered caramel popcorn again!!!

text:
Oh Yeah Baby! This is the best stuff ever! Highly addictive. My regular popcorn didn't pop, I guess it was old, so I used microwave butter flavor popcorn and it came out pretty rich, but awesome! Plenty of caramel for the corn too which I loved, as some recipes I've used before you had to work really hard to get the caramel even on all the pieces, this was not like that. I even added couple of cups more popcorn since I had so much caramel. I dumped this out onto parchment paper and broke into pieces immediately. It'a easier that way because if you wait til it's cooled you get a lot of broken popcorn pieces. Do take the time to pick out the unpopped kernals first though before adding the caramel. My DH described this best after eating an entire bowl, "This stuff is sinful!". I'll be walking an extra mile tomorrow because I just had to eat a bunch of this... oh, but it's worth every step.

dateLastModified:
2007-03-30T22:10:30.713
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
2295881
Display Name:
SarahS
isPro:
False
followersCount:
9
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
41
favoritesCount:
20
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/413590.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used dark corn syrup for this because I didn't have light.. I have seen several recipes for caramel popcorn that called for dark but I do think light works best here.  I really think the key to making successful caramel popcorn is to watch the salt.  its best to start with unsalted popcorn so you have control over how much goes in.  And definitely make sure you dont get any unpopped corn kernels in the popcorn before adding the syrup.. it ruins it when you unexpectedly bite down into a hard kernel (since it gets stuck to the popcorn).  The first time I made this, I mixed in some candy corn (after baking) since it was around Halloween time and we had some leftover.  The last time I made this I mixed in peanut m&ms after the caramel popcorn was done and cooled off.

Perfect!  I've made this 3 times now.  The first time, it was perfect.  The second time I grabbed the wrong salt (fake stuff).  Don't use fake salt or reduced sodium salt.  It will curdle the caramel.  When I made my third batch, I used regular (morton) salt and it worked perfectly.  I also added pecans and almonds... wow!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The trick here is in the preparation.  
* First I pop 3 regular size bags of Natural flavor microwave popcorn & place them in a huge (10 gal!)round cooler & sift out the old maids. 
* Preheat the oven to 300F (hard crack temp) & line 2 half sheet pans with parchment.
* Follow recipe as written.  
Notes: Either light/dark corn syrup or brown sugar are fine.  Mixture will foam and double in size when soda is added.  
* Cook for 10 minutes, then stir & cook 10 more minutes.  
* Return the cooked popcorn to the bowl & stir occasionally until completely cooled to keep it from clumping up.

text:
I actually went through all the reviews to pick up tips, and I tried it today and it is GLORIOUS. I did two batches - one baked and one unbaked. The unbaked batch was great - all gooey and decadent but I REALLY recommend baking the popcorn because the end result is a crisp, light coating on the popcorn. The caramel/toffee flavor also "matures", in a sense, which doesn't make it too heavy.
It is rather too sweet, but what can I expect from caramel popcorn? Soaking the pan and utensils in hot, soapy water was the best tip I ever laid on eyes on - wash up was ridiculously easy. I'm keeping this one until I'm on my rocker - thanks!

text:
After reading all the reviews about this being messy to stir I realized I didn't have a big enough bowl to put the all popcorn with the hot sticky caramel. I wondered how it would work if I dumped everything in the kitchen sink and mixed it up? It was just the perfect size! I also used long salad tongs to mix it up and was able to avoid burning my hands. The best part was clean up afterwards...just hot soapy water in the sink! I used two 13 x 9 pans to put in the oven.

Three bags of salted popcorn and the entire caramel recipe was the perfect comination for me and just the right sweetness...we just had a party for fifteen people (kids and adults) and it was gone in less than fifteen minutes! Yum!!!!

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yes, this is quite good.  Here are a few tips that I think really helped me when I made this.  First, I used DARK corn syrup and LIGHT brown sugar.  I did not see anybody mention this, so I thought it might be important.  Also, I did halve the recipe, and I did "run out" of the caramel before I ran out of popcorn-- mainly because I like a heavier coating (my batch is much more clustery).  Also, thr BEST thing to do here is pop your own popcorn on the stovetop-- it's not at all greesy or salty that way, and it simply tastes better then anything coming from the microwave.  

To halve the recipe, I popped 1/2 cup of regular popping corn (and had few unpopped kernels), and that yielded roughly 12-13 cups of popcorn.  If you want an estimate of how much a halved recipe yields when all is said and done..  I have just over one large mixing bowl full of caramel popcorn now, which would be good for 1-2 people when they are watching a movie or something.  If you have kids or something, you fir sure want to make the full batch as indicated in the original recipe.  :)

text:
Overall I thought this was a great recipe.  I would just like to add a couple of suggestions.  First, I think that you could easily make 6 or 7 quarts of popcorn rather than the suggested 5.  Secondly, I thought that it was a tad salty (especially when using microwave popcorn that's pre-salted), so I recommend leaving out the salt.  Lastly, be sure to grease your pans!  I didn't and it was very hard to scrape up the popcorn without breaking it up.

text:
I am now famous for this popcorn!  My daughter called it *sticky popcorn* and now it is my #1 requested recipe!  I use margarine instead of butter, half the recipe for the toffee, and use 2 bags of popcorn. Use a tinfoil/cooking spray combo on your baking sheets and you won't have to worry about sticking.  Whoever is throwing out pans, stop it!  Hot soapy water and a little time to soak will melt the sugar right off. Oh, be sure to follow the baking procedure, stirring every 15 minutes if you don't want the toffee to pull out your fillings!

text:
This popcorn is absolutely delicious! I used two bags of microwave popcorn and had plenty of carmel to coat it all. I made clean up easy by lining my baking sheets in foil (greased, of course), and then simply disposing of the foil. Also, I recommend running really hot water with a bit of soap in the pan(s) that you use to make the caramel sauce. Let it sit for 30 min or so. The hot, soapy water liquifies the carmel and you won't have a sticky mess to clean up!

text:
I really love this recipe, and have been making it for about a year now.  I air-popped about a cup and a half of popcorn kernels and that amount seemed to be just right.  I also mix and bake the whole thing in a huge restaurant-sized tinfoil pan, which I keep washing and reusing for this purpose.  I also baked the corn for about 45 minutes and that worked out well for me.  Not so crispy that the kernels break up when you stir it or grab some, but not so soft that it rips your dental fillings out.  Very easy and very successful recipe!

text:
WOW WEE!!!! It is DELICIOUS!!!  Honest to Pete.......aboslutely wonderful.  Way better than Crunch and Munch!!!!!  I followed the recipe exactly and cooked for the whole hour. PERFECT!!!!!  One thing that I thought made things a little easier.  I have the BIG Tupperware Salad Bowl.  I put the popcorn in that bowl and then poured the caramel mixture over.  Then put the lid on the bowl and shake, shake, shake.  It coated everything well, much easier than trying to stir it with a spoon with popcorn flying out of the bowl.  Worked great.  I also used aluminum foil baking pans sprayed with Pam.  No problems at all!!!  IT IS SO GOOD!!!!!!

text:
OHHHH MYYYYYY GOOOOODNESSSSSSS!!!  If I could give more than 5 stars to this recipe, I would.  Absolutely wonderful!  The only change I made to the recipe was the addition of about 1/2 cup of blister peanuts (very crunchy peanuts found at Trader Joe's) to the popcorn before drizzling in the caramel, which I found easy to do using a large spoon, instead of pouring from the pan.  Also, I was out of light corn syrup (making too many batches of Coconut Brittle, also found on this site), so I used dark, and it was wonderful.  I baked mine for the recommended time, in 2 - 9 x 13 inch baking dishes, lined with Reynolds Release foil (one of the BEST inventions in the world, I think! lol).  Cleanup was a breeze.  My Dentist thanks you for giving us this awesome recipe!

text:
I have made this twice, exactly as written both times, and it turned out perfectly both times. I used 1 cup of uncooked popcorn kernels and the ratio of caramel to popcorn was perfect. I followed another reviewer's suggestion and continued stirring the popcorn after it finished cooking, as it cooled, to prevent caramel pooling underneath & to prevent large clumps.
To make extra special caramel corn for a special event, I melted some Hershey kisses and drizzled over the cooked caramel corn.

This is by far the best caramel popcorn ever! It is not sticky whatsoever, so the kiddos can eat it in front of the tv for "movie night", no worries there. It is crunchy, but in a crumbly way, not the "you're about to lose a tooth" way. The flavor is amazing.

text:
I've been making this recipe for 40 years!  Passed down to me from my Grandma Alderson, who said she got it from the back of a JiffyPop bag!!  When my daughter was in high school, I made several batches of this (each batch makes a considerable amount) to send with her youth group on a mission trip.  Many of her friends still remember me as the 'Caramel Corn Lady'!  One tip...don't use generic brown sugar.  It tends to granulate more and just doesn't taste as good.  I always use quality, name brand light brown sugar.  Also, please, PLEASE don't use margarine for this!  No reason to waste good ingredients by using margarine.  =)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
As written I had problems with this recipe. Although I was following the directions exactly the carmel would either burn in the oven within the first 15 minutes or turned out so granulated that it hurt the tongue to eat. I just couldn't believe that the recipe had so many perfect reviews so I kept trying to get this recipe to work. I finally came across Sarah's review and took her advice. Increased Corn syrup to 3/4 cup and baking soda to a full teaspoon and reduced salt to 1/2 teaspoon. It turned out great with those changes!!!! I melted down some Hersheys HUGS and drizzled on top. Soo Yummy! I also noticed that I had to increase the amount of popped popcorn to 3/4 cup uncooked kernels. 1/2 was too little and would cause the carmel to be too thick which would cause it to be grainy as well.

text:
This was super easy to make. I followed some other reviewers and used 1/2 cup butter, not the full cup. I thought it was still buttery without being greasy. It was crunchy and buttery and sweet. Very easy to make!! Next time, and there WILL  be a next time, I'll put the popcorn into a large bowl and mix in the coating. I tried to mix it right on the baking sheet and it was a bit tricky. It didn't set up all that fast, so if I work quick, it should be just fine. I baked the popcorn on trays that were covered with greased tin foil and had no issues. If you let the pan and spoon sit in some hot,soapy water for a bit, they come clean with very little scrubbing.

userID:
10918924
Display Name:
aliceinthekitchen
isPro:
False

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this and everyone loved it and I've done it several times now. I used plain yellow popcorn kernels and popped them in a paper bag in the microwave. Just one layer on the bottom of the bag for 2 and a half minutes until I had enough to fill 2 foil pans. 

For the caramel make sure when you measure, you pack the brown sugar in so you actually get 2 cups. And it's important to use medium heat, you don't want to bring it to the boil too quickly and you must stir constantly. Leave it alone on a low boil for the 4 minutes and don't forget to remove it from the heat before you add the baking soda and vanilla.

We don't like it too sweet so I only add just enough caramel to coat but not completely drown the corn. I also only stir it once at 15 minutes and then take it out 15 minutes after that and stir it once more and let it cool. Once, I didn't have enough time and it was in the oven for only 15 minutes and I turned let it cool and it was fine.
Review:

10915215
Display Name:
Sg

city:

country:
None
text:
It is fine/great just the way it is written.  I did not find any of the other reviews or suggestions useful.  I used dark brown sugar and it was fine.  Used 1cup of butter and it was great.  It did not drizzle in a stream as someone suggested. You can't if you made the Carmel correctly. I just poured the Carmel on little by little as the recipe suggests and tossed like a salad. I did not warm the popcorn before adding the carmel.  It surprises me that people don't know how to cook popcorn on the stove...maybe they had to change the recipe because they used microwave popcorn?  I popped enough popcorn to fill a very large wooden salad bowl and the amount of Carmel was perfect.  I think I popped 4 medium sized pots of it. Probably would fill a brown paper grocery bag 3/4 of the way.  Recipe is great.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2012-12-01T14:57:44.093
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
3479162
Display Name:
T C
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Holy moly! This is delicious!  I am not a big caramel fan, but this popcorn is fabulous!  It is light, with a crispy shell that is the perfect thickness to compliment the light and airy popcorn inside.  I, like other reviewers, used a 1/2 lb (one stick) of butter.  I also put the popcorn in a large turkey roasting pan, like someone suggested, and I can't imagine doing it another way. It made it really easy to stir the popcorn every 15 minutes.  I wanted to experiment, so after the third stir, I added peanuts,  I realized this was too late.  I would suggest adding them to the caramel mixture before you add in the baking soda and vanilla.  This is when you normally add peanuts to peanut brittle, and I think if I poured the syrup on with the nuts mixed in, they would have stuck.  Once the popcorn was done baking, I took half of it and spread it out on parchment and then left the other half in the pan and threw in 1 1/2 cups of chocolate chips.  I can't decide which version I like better.  I think I am going to do this again (one half regular and one half chocolate) and let them cool, break them up and then mix them together so you can get a bite of each one!  Thank you for a great recipe!

text:
LOVE THIS!  We used microwave popcorn so we didn't add the extra salt.  We used the Simply Salted by Orville Redenbacher.  We used 4 bags which is 4.5 cups popped/each.  The more popcorn versus carmel mixture, the crunchier.  We mixed in a large kettle and then spread out on two shallow pans and baked.  Will definitely make again.

text:
Fantastic, easy, quick recipe.  Almost fool proof!  I used recipe calculator and split recipe in half and turned out great. My only small goof was that I stirred the caramel frequently after it boiled (instead of NOT stirring at all once it started boiling) and it was just a tiny bit grain in some bites.  No one but me noticed it. I also made another batch and had to use microwave popcorn since I was all out of raw kernels. I just omitted the salt and it still worked beautifully!  Definitely a do over and will consider adding nuts next time.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe twice in 2 days.  We bagged it as part of our year end gifts for our kids' teachers.  I followed the recipe exactly as written the 1st time...it was delish!  the 2nd time I added peanuts to 1/2 of the batch, result...awesome.  I also cut the cooking time the 2nd go round to 1/2 hour turning at 15 mins.  The only other thing I did differently was break apart and remove from the baking trays when it was cool enough to touch.  I found that when I left it to cool completely the 1st time, I had hard chunks where the caramel pooled while it cooled.  I prefer it softer/chewier.  I can see how this will quickly become a family favorite!  So good, and so easy!!

text:
Honestly the best & easiest caramel popcorn ever!  I hand popped about 1 cup of popcorn on the stovetop to make this recipe.  I only needed to bake for 15 minutes, turned then another 15 minutes and it was perfect.   I also used the leftover carmel and let if sit for a moment before spooning it into wax paper, rolled & cinched the edges to make caramel candies.  FANTASTIC recipe.  My whole family loved it!

text:
I got this recipe from our Rodeo Director when she made it for one of our committee meetings; but I came to the website to find out how much unpopped corn, equals 5 quarts of popped popcorn. I do not know that answer, but I did pop 1 cup of unpopped popcorn in a hot air popcorn popper, and used that amount. My turkey roaster was filled up, with just enough room to add the caramel mixture and stir to coat. It is by far, the best caramel popcorn I have ever had. I was amazed at how evenly it was coated after it was done. I did bake it for the full 1 hour also. Yummy~Nummy treat! YeeHaw~~

This is a wonderful base recipe for caramel corn.  It marries the perfect level of sweet and salty with a super crunch!   I changed mine up a little for fall and added about 5 ozs of dehydrated crushed apple chips to make caramel apple corn and it is wonderful!   Just follow the recipe minus about 2 cups of popcorn and add the apple chips in with the popcorn.  It's a definite keeper for us!

text:
This is the first time I made this for Christmas gifts. It was so yummy! My hubby couldn't stop eating it. I had to race with him to pack the popcorn into Christmas packages. I bought Old Fashion Style Demerara sugar (it has refiner's syrup and caramel) by mistake. I used it anyway. It turned out great. It might have added extra caramel flavor to it. I used 3 bags of microwave popcorn and added  1 cup each of roasted peanuts and almonds as it suggested in the instructional video. The popcorn and nuts were still well-coated. Thank you for the great recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe!  I used more popped corn to caramel than the recipe called for because I don't like it overly sweet.  I think I waited too long to pour the caramel because it turned "gloppy" and thick. However once it was in the oven and stirred, it melted again and turned out just great.  Once it finally came out of the oven, I gave it a sprinkling of salt for some depth of flavour and it was amazing!  I recommend this for those who especially like that sweet/savoury combination.  Peeled peanuts added to the caramel would make this taste just like Crunch N' Munch.  I gave this 4 starts instead of 5 because I found it too plain for my tastes (and hence the salt).  Definately keeping this recipe!

Display Name:
sweet_firefly

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1185551.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so easy. I took some other people's advice and made the caramel in the microwave. I had popped some popcorn already and put it in a paper grocery bag. I used three bags of standard microwave popcorn. Then I poured the caramel over the popcorn and shook up the bag. Then microwaved for 30 seconds and shook some more (and repeated this process 3-4 times). Then I poured it out onto aluminum foil to fully set. I thought the amount of popcorn I used was about right, but you could use less popcorn to get a heavier coating. It was so delicious. My husband doesn't particularly like popcorn (like the movie theater kind), but he gobbled this up. I will definitely make this again!

This is the same recipe my Mom and Grandmother have always used, except we use 6 qts of popcorn.  I always use airpopped popcorn because it pops up big and fluffy and tastes better. We boil the caramel for 5 mins instead of 4.  My Mom does the entire hour, but I like it after 45 mins.  Great to give away for the holidays (if there is any left!)

This was a great recipe to start with, but I tried some of the other reviewers suggestions. The first batch I just cut the butter in half. Then the sugar was too much, but still tasted good. The next day and batch #2 I cut the butter and sugar in half and left everything else the same, and we have the perfect caramel corn now. I did used my air popper to make the popcorn. Thank you!

text:
Golden!  Tried it at every 15 minute interval and it was best after the full hour in the oven.  I tossed the popcorn in a brown paper bag as I slowly drizzled syrup... blobs of syrup that fall will spread out if you shake it while it's still hot/soft.  I transfered it to a large lighty sprayed baking sheet and baked according to recipe.  I think this is the first time that I've had caramel popcorn without the popcorn being stale!  I'll be giving this away to my special friends during the holidays.

text:
This was a hit! I did experiment with the baking time. I left a little out after each 15 minute interval and let it cool.  I sampled each time and found that the best texture and flavor was after the 3rd 15 minute stir (45 minutes total bake time).  An hour is just a bit too long and made the sugar more granular.

This caramel corn is CLASSIC!!!  It is either as good or better than the stuff you get at the market or fair.  It is very sweet, but oooh so good! photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/413397.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This popcorn is GREAT!  The only popcorn I had available was Microwaveable Act II Butter Lovers.  I used 3 packages of it and cut the butter to 1/2 cup.  I thought this would compensate for the butter flavoring already in the popcorn and also give it a heavier coating.  (Each package of popcorn makes 1 quart)  I used a large pot knowing that when I added the baking soda it would foam up.  It sure did!  Because the pot was fairly heavy, there was no drizzling.  (I kept the popcorn warm in a roasting pan until it was time to add the mixture, as others suggested).  I dumped it on and mixed the best I could.   I used a silicone spatula and it worked wonderfully.  I set the timer at 15 minute intervals for mixing.  After 30 minutes, I took it from the roasting pan and spread it out on two cookie trays that were sprayed with "pam".  Then I baked them another 15 minutes.  I had to use a roasting pan first so I would have room for mixing.  It turned out really tasty.  My daughter-in-law stopped in and said it was better than what they buy on the boardwalk!

text:
This is the best caramel popcorn I have EVER eaten.  It is buttery, crunchy and wickedly good.  I didnt have regular corn syrup, so I used light "Light Corn Syrup w/ Vanilla" and halved the vanilla in the recipe to make up the diff.  Dont worry if you start to pour the caramel and think you wont have enough.  You will!  I sort of flipped the popcorn instead of stirring to avoid braking it up.  I also bought popcorn kernals and cooked them on the stove.  Easy and cheap.

text:
I have never made caramel popcorn before, so I wasn't sure what kind of results to expect.  I followed the directions exactly, then added 2 cups of pecans before baking in the oven.  I divided the popcorn/pecans between 2 foil turkey pans that were coated with nonstick spray.  I stirred every 10 minutes for an hour, then spread out into a single layer on my dinner table to cool.  The popcorn turned out absolutely perfect.  The pecans roasted nicely and have a wonderful praline taste and crunch to them.  I will most definitely be packaging these up and giving as gifts this Christmas!!

text:
I have tried a few cadied popcorn recipes, and this one came out much bettern than the recipe where the caramel has to be boiled for 15 minutes!  By then it tasted burnt. I was skeptical at first about the 4 minute method, but this has great buttery flavor, and quite addictive.  But, I DID embellish this a bit, and improved upon perfection.   I got some cinnamon roasted almonds, and some maple flavored candied nut mix from a super "W" grocery store, and coarsely chopped them up and sprinkled them all over the caramel before I mixed it all up, and all I can say is it's like going to a state fair!  I will make this again.  And it's kid approved. My kid loved it.

region:
