country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe! This is the second time I have made it...the first time, it turned out grainy, as one review mentioned. After thinking about it, it turns out that I just dumped all of the caramel ingredients into the pan all at once (except for the vanilla). I think it's the baking soda that makes the difference.  Looks like when I put it in before boiling the caramel, the caramel corn ends up looking grainy (though believe me, it didn't stop us from eating it!) This time, I put it in as instructed by the recipe (hmm, maybe I should read it more closely!) The caramel corn came out completely non-grainy. The cost of the ingredients didn't seem to make a difference at all. Now, if you'll excuse me, I've got some caramel corn to tend to...

Great.  Way more caramel than needed for 5 Qts of popcorn- more like 8 qts. Substituted honey for half of the corn syrup. Also, I boiled the sauce longer.  If you want a chewier result, cook only 30 min in oven, take out, form in balls if you want. It's stickier and chewier. I like both.

text:
Fantastic Caramel Corn recipe.  This is the 1st one I've tried and I have no reason to try any others.  There are not many recipes I've made that people actually fought over, but this one made that happen.  Make sure you have a very large bowl on hand for mixing the corn and syrup mix - it takes some room.  Also, per another review, I warmed the already popped corn in the oven prior to coating with the caramel.  It took 2 1/2 bags of microwave popcorn to get the 5 quarts called for in this recipe.  Finally, I toasted 1 cup of whole almonds and added that to the recipe.  This was great.  Thanks, Brian.

text:
I took the advice of many of the reviewers; cut the butter in half and only baked the popcorn for about 1/2 hour (though I would only let it go for 45 minutes max if I were you!)

Cutting the butter in 1/2 makes the caramel a little harder to work with, but it thins out a little in the oven. Maybe try cutting the sugars down a bit if you use less butter.

Awesome, easy recipe!

text:
I make this every year for my daughter's middle school teachers as Christmas gifts. They LOVE it, as does my family.  One teacher wanted to ORDER some from me last year!  :+)  I add a cup of almonds and a cup of pecans to each batch.  My secret ingredient is the popcorn; my husband's cousins grow popcorn on their farm for Weaver (Boy Scouts) and Orville Redenbacher.  We use popcorn straight from the field, which tends to pop larger than store bought.  You may want to consider trying gourmet popcorn with this recipe, if your results aren't as expected. It really makes the difference.

text:
This is one of my signature desserts! I pop my own kernels on the stove in oil. Important to have a BIG bowl to stir the caramel into the popcorn. Watch the oven temp when you bake and keep stirring to not burn the sugar. I did that the first few times. I sprinkle course salt while it's still sticky. Sweet and salty!

text:
I knew it was going to be good based on the reviews. But, I didn't expect such a PERFECT buttery, caramelized, crunchy glaze! This is soooo much better than store bought.
I followed the advice of others and kept my popped corn heated in my big blue broiler (lined with wax paper) while the caramel cooked. I placed nuts in my caramel after I finished cooking, then drizzled. I only stirred the corn 2 times and couldn't take it anymore.... we had to try it. We poured it onto waxed paper and let cool for only 30 minutes. Great!

Cooking time was 45 minutes for us.  The only problem:  Not having enough willpower to stop eating all the kernals!  What a great recipe; I'll be making this again.

text:
This popcorn is addictive!  I made a half batch and cooked it in two pans at the same time side by side in the oven.  I had used a deep lasagna pan and a regular 9 x 13 cake pan.  I had a hard time turning the popcorn in the 9 x 13 pan, much easier in the deeper lasagna pan.    I lined both pans with aluminum foil and sprayed them with butter flavor pam as well.

This is so good!  I used yellow kernels and popped them in the air-popper, just one batch, and then followed the recipe, a little less salt and baked around 50 minutes or so.  It was as close to Garrett's as I've ever come - and I've been trying for three years!  Seemed to help when I stirred quickly instead of carefully at the 15 minute intervals since the caramel hardens quickly.

text:
This recipe has a nice balance of sweet / salty flavor.  I used a natural flavor butter popcorn and unsalted butter due to the saltiness of the popcorn.  I halved the recipe and baked the popcorn mixture at 250 in a lightly greased 13 x 9 metal baking pan (as per the recipe), turning every 15 minutes for 45 minutes, as the popcorn mixture did not need a full hour to bake.  I believe next time I make this recipe, I will mix macadamia nuts with the popcorn before adding the caramel mixture to compliment the butter flavor.

text:
Excellent. Nice buttery flavor. Saved me a trip to the mall to get caramel popcorn :).

One big mistake I did was using waxed paper. When the popcorns cooled it got stuck to the paper and I could not separate the paper from the pan without ripping it. I had to put it back into the oven to melt it so I could put it into a bowl to cool.

text:
Half of the recipe and 1 bag microwave popcorn worked great but watch the temp during the 4 min. boil time ... mine burned a bit but I carefully poured what wasn't burned over the popcorn and carried on. Nice and crisp but a little dark (my fault). Use Pam on foil on a cookie sheet for the oven part. Be sure to separate the cooked popcorn from the uncooked kernels before you add the caramel. NO chipped teeth for us! Also I wouldn't add any more salt if the popcorn already tastes salty. This recipe is easy and hubby is happily crunching away!

text:
Absolutely awesome!!  I messed around with the recipe @ the reviews...3 bags of popcorn, etc, trying to do more at a time. I found it was best done with 2 bags of popcorn and just as written...awesome!  FYI...3 bags/standard caramel, coverage too light; 4 bags with double caramel, too much caramel (puddles).  I baked 1 1/2 hrs and still had puddles, but it was absolutely delicious...actually better than the standard recipe.

I was worried baking it so long would burn it, but it came out beautifully, crunchy & sweet.  Will be making again!
The recipe instructs you to stir a few times during baking--don't be tempted to skip that.  The stirring helps avoid clumps of caramel.  On the other hand, clumps of caramel is not necessarily a bad thing.

first recipe eating ever :) it was that good. made these as xmas gifts this year and they were a hit! ended up making 60 mason jars of these ??

tweaks: 
- used 3/4 cup of butter (if not adding nuts just use half cup)
- added cups of walnuts, peanuts and almonds

userID:
16921985
Display Name:
Athena
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
11
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3086600.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe a year ago have been making it regularly at least twice a month since! It's the BEST caramel popcorn I have ever tasted. Everyone who tries it becomes instantly addicted. I make it so much because everyone is constantly asking for more. I've give it away at holiday parties and just as regular (and often pleaded for) gift to a few entire floors of hard working nurses at the hospital where my husband works. The only changes I've ever made are to cut down the butter to 1 and a half sticks. There is really no noticeable difference in taste or texture by doing this - I do it when I'm low on butter/margarine and just make do with what I have. Oh and sometimes I add pecans, peanuts, almonds, cashews.. etc, any type of nut is delicious with this! To anyone who says their popcorn came out of the oven burnt I suggest you check that your oven is running at the right temperature. I had my oven calibrated and use a separate temperature gauge inside and it runs at the display temperature. At 250 degrees F for an hour with stirring every 15 minutes I've never had a burning issue. You must make sure to mix up all the popcorn that is at the bottom of the pan. I don't use two pans - I use one giant roaster. I use a stove top Whirley Pop to make the popcorn and exactly two full pots of popcorn (1/2c of kernals for each popping so 1c of kernals per batch of this caramel corn ) makes the *perfect* amount of popcorn. This stores in an airtight container very well for a few days

text:
Loved IT!!!! This recipe makes a gallon Ziplock bag and it will not last. I was so scared to make caramel corn but not anymore. My only change was I only used 1/2 cup butter. I also used 1/2 cup unpopped corn as suggested by other reviews. The caramel covered all the popcorn perfectly. My suggestion is to check your caramel corn after every 15 minutes to see how crunchy it is. I found after half an hour that it was cooked perfect.... I also used a large roasting pan and keep the popcorn in the oven to keep warm and found that I had no problem mixing it with the sauce. I also suggest spraying the final cookie sheet with a cooking spray to avoid sticking.... Will be making this recipe over and over again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2785047.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe many times, and it is fantastic as written. If you like nuts, you can add your favorite (our family likes cocktail peanuts). To really put it "over the top," I mix a cup of white chocolate chips with 1 teaspoon coconut oil, in a Ziplock bag, melt very carefully in the microwave, cut the corner off, and drizzle over caramel corn, after its final round in the oven. Let it cool until the chocolate "sets," then break it into pieces. If you have added nuts, try to stir them to the top as much as possible, and the drizzling of chocolate will also help them "stick" to the caramel corn better. I have also tried milk chocolate...don't care much for it...haven't yet tried semi-sweet, or butterscotch. The white chocolate complements the caramel corn favors best. It does make it sweeter, but it sure is GOOD! Happy cooking/baking! :)
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-12-24T09:37:22.4
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
8368787
Display Name:
Rachael Dixon Reczenski
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
42
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7109202.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for my family's Thanksgiving.  I also made kettle corn and cookies and so on and so forth.  The Caramel Popcorn was gone SO fast!  It was a great munchie before dinner and a great desert snack instead of eating heavy pieces of pie after dinner.  
The timing I used was a little different.  I boiled on med-low heat, stirring constantly.  
I was also taught a different method to tell how it's done.  Have a bowl of cold water ready next to you at the stove and drizzle a little caramel in the cold water.  If it sinks and is still soft, keep boiling (and stirring constantly.)  If its instantly hard (not "kinda" hard) and floats, you're done!  
I also tried this with and without the baking soda and I liked it a LOT more without the baking soda.  Much better color and consistency without it.

country:
None
text:
This is the best recipe for Carmel popcorn ever!  I prefer to call it Toffee Popcorn because of the creamy buttery texture and flavor. I add peanuts to the mix which adds another level of goodness. 
I find that a large roasting pan works best. Make sure you stir frequently so that the Carmel coats evenly over all the popcorn. 
I usually break my popcorn up by just shaking the pan as soon as it comes out of the oven as it cools quickly.  I prefer smaller individual pieces as it is easier to eat and package as gifts.  This recipe will keep for weeks if stored in a sealed container or zip lock baggies.

text:
This recipe turned out well using microwave popcorn (3 bags), although I thought the popcorn became rather hard after cooling.  I would suggest breaking into large chunks of popcorn before it settles and totally cools off.  Quite a bit of popcorn stuck to the bottom of the pan and didn't break up well.  I used 2 shallow glass pans ( 9 x 13) and cooked at 250 degrees for the total time suggested and stirred about 4 times.  I did work hard to get all of the kernels coated by stirring, turning large sections over etc. and scraping the bottom of pans to not waste the sticky goodness.  Turned out really great.  Lowering cooking time (as others suggested) may help the hardening and sticking to the pan and to break apart better.

Rating:
5

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great!  I used half the butter called for in the recipe and ended up popping more popcorn.  I wanted the popcorn to be in individual pieces, so I didn't completely coat the popcorn with the syrup (thus the additional need for more popcorn to be popped).  I didn't have to break it apart....and there was plenty of flavor without the popcorn being 100% coated.   Placed a portion of the popcorn in a large stockpot (sprayed with cooking spray), drizzled syrup, stirred.  Then added more popcorn, drizzled syrup, stirred, repeating until all popcorn was used.  This made for easy distribution of the syrup.  Baked for 45 mins in pans lined with baking paper for easy clean up. Thank you for this recipe!  Move over Cracker Jacks! :-)

country:
None
text:
My go-to caramel popcorn recipe! 1/2 this recipe makes enough for 2 bags of popped microwave popcorn. Even works with dark corn syrup. 
If I'm just making a little to eat during a movie, I don't bother baking it. If you want a harder crunch, you can crank up the heat and bake it at 350 for 30 minutes or less (stir closer to every 5 minutes). I prefer the tender crunch of the 250 deg./1 hr plan if I'm not in a hurry.

text:
Wonderful, simple recipe-- I took off one star because adding the caramel to WARM popcorn is key and not mentioned except by other reviewers. Luckily, I used a large turkey roaster and had enough left over for a 9 x 13 baking dish. The popcorn in the baking dish cooled quickly and was virtually unmixable-- while the turkey roaster held more heat and blended up like a charm. I find the result comparable to fresh fair or farmer's market caramel corn-- much better than anything store bought!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:

userID:
758892
Display Name:
Billie Nguyen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
20
favoritesCount:
417
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3439238.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just got a Presto popcorn maker and some gourmet "High Mountain Midnight" popcorn kernels from Fireworks popcorn and wanted to try caramel corn.  I didn't want to make a thick coating of caramel so I halved the recipe, AND then halved the butter, so that I used 1/4 cup butter. Didn't have corn syrup, so substituted with Lyles Golden syrup.  I popped the popcorn & set aside.  Made the syrup. Discarded unpopped kernels.  Put 1/2 of popcorn into brown paper bag, drizzled 1/2 of syrup over it and shook it around.  Closed the bag and microwaved 30 seconds on High.  Shook it around again and poured into large bowl to cool.  Then I put the syrup back on the heat to melt and repeated the steps again with the rest of the popcorn.  Very easy via microwave instead of baking for an hour, and easy to clean up! Thanks to everyone who gave helpful hints!

text:
This recipe is delicious.  The baking time in the oven is just to harden the caramel.  The softer/chewier you want the caramel, the less time you bake it for.  Definitely spray your bowl before you add the caramel to your popcorn, it will save you a lot of time cleaning.  Also, spray your cookie sheets.  I will make this again to hand out to friends as part of my Christmas goodies tray...

text:
I have tried other recipes and this one is the best, my trick is ( along with the biggest turkey roasting pan I could find ) I put a large piece of parchment paper in the bottom of the pan. I have to hold that paper in place while mixing but that is super easy to do. I also stir much more often than the recipe calls for. About every 10 min. This ensures an even coating. Tastes great. And yes, like most others have said, you will make more. Promise!

text:
This was way better than I ever imagined :) Love it! I've been dreaming of a caramel popcorn since I first tasted some in Garretts popcorn shop in NYC in 2008. Thought about ordering a batch on the internet a few times but found a bit expensive so after much consideration I decided to try making my own.   Where as I don't live in the US, I didn't find corn syrup in the store so I bought Lyle's golden syrup but I don't think that it made a difference. It is just as good as Garrett's caramel popcorn, if not better if it's possible ;)

text:
Easy gourmet popcorn.  I followed another reviewer by having my oven at 300F and stirring it every 10 minuted for only 20 minutes.  Fast and delicious!

Update: I made this two more times and now it always come out grainy, not sure why.  The only difference is that I'm using safeway brown sugar now and before it was walmart brown sugar.  I'll try one more batch using walmart brand and see if sugar is the reason, I haven't changed anything else.

None
text:
I love this recipe, but I've always changed it a bit and haven't put it in the oven. Instead, around the time the caramel starts to boil, I begin popping the popcorn in the air popper. Once the caramel has boiled for it's 4 minutes, I take it off the heat and add the baking soda and vanilla. After stirring it, I place it back on the heat until the caramel has gotten a bit fluffy. Then I pour it onto the popcorn, and stir it all in.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is god sent, I have been craving for caramel popcorn but have been wanting to make it myself. It was simple and easy to make, and I made dinner while baking it.    I did cut down the recipe since I only had 1/2 pound of butter left and I measured out 10 cups of popcorn with my pyrex measuring cup.    I air popped my popcorn and greased everything that was going to be used in this process (with the melted butter) excluding the mixing bowl, wasn't too bad to clean up.    I did bake it for the full hour and when it was cooling I mixed it constantly until it was hard to the touch, that way my kernels were separate. Now I just have to stop eating it!

text:
Great recipe.  I used 2 bags of microwave popcorn and added a couple cups of nuts.  line the oven pans with parchment.  The candy does not stick to the parchment, also if using a dark pan the white parchment keeps the candy from burning (not to mention making clean-up a breeze).

Took the advice from others and scaled down the butter to 1 stick and followed the microwave directions.  What a breeze.  One thing to be aware of... make sure you don't use a ceramic bowl to microwave in as it burned the heck out of my hands.  The paper bag idea and lining the baking sheet was genius.  No fuss no muss!

text:
I haven't even finished making this yet and I can't keep my fingers out of it! Every time I stir it, I have to sneak a little bit. A tip: for anyone having problems coating your popcorn, just make stovetop popcorn while you're making the caramel sauce. It coats BEAUTIFULLY! (AND you won't have to worry about it being too buttery or salty because the caramel sauce will be the only flavor on it)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not that this recipe needs the ratings but here are afew more tips.  for 1-2 ppl, I used 2 bags of microwave popcorn and 1/2 the recipe above. I used the equivalent of 3/4c of butter for the full recipe.  Use 3-4 bags of microwave popcorn per full recipe depending on how much candy coating you like.  For a lighter color end result, I used brown sugar and light "clear" corn syrup.  this will give you a creamed coffee color.  Added a tsp of cinnamon as well. Definitely keep your popcorn warmed in the oven until syrup is read to be poured. I baked 15m, mixed, and another 20m, mixed and let rest.  That's 40 min total and it was fine. Awesome easy recipe.  For those who can't make this, keep at it.  And if you still can't get it right, find another hobby. :)

text:
This is very good.  I made something similar on a different recipe site that used the crunchy hard Cheetos instead of popcorn.  This is definitely less fattening than that recipe!  I used 1 stick of butter and it came out great.  I used a hot air popper to make the popcorn and wish I knew how much raw popcorn made 5 quarts of popped corn.  I am sure that fact is out there but I didn't have time to look it up.  I just used 1/2 a cup of raw popcorn kernels in the hot air popper.  Seems to be perfect.  Doesn't seem to make that much.  It all fit in a gallon ziploc bag after it had cooled from the oven.

text:
delicious! i followed the advice of the other reviews: used only half of the amount of butter and kept the popcorn warm in the oven until ready to put the caramel on.  in addition, since i didn't have corn syrup, i substituted with clover honey and it came out just as good; the honey gave it a nice, slight nutty flavor to it.  lastly, i cut the recipe in half which came out to equal about 2 bags of popped popcorn.  this was really great and addicting! definitely will be making more!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This popcorn is great and fairly easy to make! I halved the recipe and used 1 1/2 bags popped butter popcorn. It still tasted great although next time I think I'll try and use plain popcorn. My husband loves it and it's a great way to use up those bags of popcorn sitting around (we both don't really care for plain or buttered popcorn). It would also make a nice gift to give someone. 5 stars for sure!  Update: The first time I made this, I forgot to add the baking soda and vanilla. It came out like the caramel popcorn you buy and tasted great. The only complaint was that there were chunks of the coating that were really chewy. I just made this again and added the baking soda. It immediately puffed up and wouldn't go back down (runny and sticky) when baking and so it's all light and fluffy, not like candy, more soft. I think it worked better without the baking soda.

I made this for my fiance and he loved it!!! There were 2 things though for me.
1. This was a sticky mess to clean up.
2. I used microwave popcorn and I did not sift through to get the unpopped kernals out. That was a mistake on my part. 

Next time, I will probably use bagged plain popcorn and spray my pans and utensils with cooking spray to prevent the sticking. Hopefully that will work.
Overall, this is a really great recipe, and I will definitely make it again.

text:
This popcorn is so amazing.  i simply can not stop eating it.  I made it from popcorn kernels popped in coconut oil.  The results are stellar!  Its light and crunchy and sweet and salty and so very buttery.  I think the real secret here is that the caramel recipe is so great.  I couldn't stop dipping my finger to eat some caramel when i was mixing it up.  The caramel is very thick and sticky, so its a little tricky to get the popcorn coated evenly, but tossing it lightly by hand worked well.  I also added some peanuts.  Delicious!

text:
Absolutely phenomenal!  Tips: makes sure you don't have any corn kernels mixed in with your popcorn, its painful on the teeth to bit down on one of those.  Second, put on greased foil...makes clean up so much better!  Lastly, add some whole nuts!  I didn't bake it as long as instructed, (about 30 mins)but I do recommend baking it, as opposed to not baking it as some of reviewers suggest, it just makes the popcorn real crispy and will help it to keep longer.  This was truly awesome!

text:
This is so yummy. I skipped the oven baking step and just stirred it all together in a huge bowl. You have to stir and break it up as it cools for a little while. An even easier way to finish it up is to just spread it out on wax paper, then every now and then break it up into smaller chunks... My kids hated waiting for it while it baked in the oven so this worked better for us. Makes it nice a chewy.. YUM! Oh I also made homemade stove top popcorn in a large pot verses using microwave.

text:
This popcorn tastes better then store bought caramel corn. The effort to make it is worth it but make sure to pour the caramel on the popcorn within a few minutes, or else the caramel sauce will thicken and not spread well. Stir every 10- 15 minutes an cook in the biggest, flattest pans you have! Also grease th4e pan because my bottom layer stuck to the   bottom. Delicioso!

text:
NOT proud to admit this, but I started eating it before it was done and couldnt stop!!
Having never made caramel popcorn before, and not being a huge caramel popcorn freak, I had somewhat low expectations, but the reviews made me curious.  
Not only did I have a bit of burned popcorn, and I added the baking soda and the vanilla BEFORE the boiling process- so I fouled it up a bit, and it still came out AMAZING!!
Reminds me of the gourmet candy and ice cream shops I used to visit as a kid.  
DH is another not-so-huge-fan of caramel popcorn, but he too could not stop eating it.  
I am 100% sure I'll be making this again-most likely very soon!! 
I dont know if I should say "Thanks for a great recipe" or "Boo! you've made me an addict" 

Easy, not too expensive to make and amazing!! Go for it!

text:
This was everything I hoped it would be. It's a little time-consuming to have to stir the popcorn in the oven every fifteen minutes, but the final product is delicious! I didn't use as much popcorn as was called for, which meant that what I did have was more caramel-coated...(ran out of room in the bowl I was stirring it in). I also didn't need the last 15 mins of cook time (I have an oven that is usually too hot), so if it seems ready before the cook time is up, then you may want to pull it out. Great snack at my Oscar Party!

text:
I cant believe I finally know how to make caramel popcorn from scratch!!! And it's soooooo good! The full recipe is too much for me and my fiance, so I halve the recipe, and I use 1 bag of microwave butter popcorn (3.5 oz),half the salt (1/4 tsp), Karo LIGHT corn syrup, and Domino's DARK brown sugar (that's what I use initially, since it turned out very good, I don't wanna change a thing). My fiance said it's better with cashews, so sometimes I throw them in. I foil and pam a 13x9 pan, and bake it for 35-40 minutes, with mixing them very well every 12-13 mins. Thank you so much for this recipe, definitely a keeper!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
DELICIOUS! I made this last night and gave them away as christmas gifts for my friends. I have to say that it does taste more like toffee than it does caramel, but it's still really good anyways. Just remember to re-coat the popcorn every once in a while when it's in the oven, because the caramel tends to pool to the bottom and slide of the popcorn. I coated my first batch with a lot of the mixture, the second, not so much; I think the most difficult thing is getting the right amount on there (I didn't have space in my oven to put it all on at once so I did it in 3 batches). The one with a lot of caramel came out ok, the second one a little burnt (be careful that this doesn't happen or else it will end up tasting bitter) because it didn't have enough coating on it. I also shortened the oven time to 45 minutes because my popcorn was already golden brown (mmm). I let it cool, mixed it with some white chocolate chips and toasted peanuts, wrapped it in cellophane and tied it with a ribbon. Great gift! Thank you for the recipe, it will definetely be made again!

FANTASTIC!!  I made it with one slight, easy variation.  Add 1-2 cups whole almonds, and use 1/2 teaspoon almond extract and 1/2 teaspoon vanilla in place of all vanilla.  The result:  Almond Toffee Popcorn -WAY better than Cracker Jack.  Baked for 45 min.  Perfect!

text:
the taste was really good, baked it for 45 minutes but felt that even that was too much time.  it was very cruncy and not soft.  i will make this again and bake for about 20 minutes next time for a more softer popcorn.
i did make a little less popcorn with the same amount of sauce which was a big mistake because it was just too sweet (usually the ones from the store with the most caramel on the popcorn are the best ones and so i thought it would be the same situation here..nope! less is much better) but that is my fault and i will definitly not cover the popcorn as much with the caramel.  but i feel that the baking time is much too long.
i will try it again with all of that in mind.

I can’t stop eating it. This popcorn is crispy yet melts in your mouth. Don’t reduce the butter, it’s not like you’re dieting if you’re eating caramel popcorn. Indulge and enjoy. I do use a very large pan and stir the popcorn into the pan of caramel instead of drizzling the caramel over the popcorn. That keeps the caramel warm and easier to incorporate.

text:
This recipe is very good but I must say reading the reviews can be so confusing. Some were saying they only used half of the butter, then said that was a half of a pound. The recipe only calls for 1 cup of butter, which IS a half of a pound. Then some said they cut the butter in half by using 1 cup of butter. Which again is what the recipe calls for. Maybe people should understand that 1 stick of butter is a half of a cup!!!! So did they use just a half of a cup of butter which would be half of what the recipe calls for or did they use 1 cup of butter thinking they were halfing it? Anyway I ended up using 1 stick of butter which is half of what was called for and it was great.

country:
None
text:
Amazing recipe! Everyone always raves, "the best caramel corn I've ever had!".  I always use an air popper for the corn, makes for a dry and ready product. Also, keeping the popcorn warm in a pan while making the caramel is crucial.  Sometimes I switch the vanilla extract for a different flavor. Coffee, pistachio, almond.  Make multiple batches, with different extracts, then blend together for a true original. Can't go wrong adding nuts! Pecans and blanched almonds are a personal favorite.

text:
Amazing!  I'm constantly asked to make this recipe!!
I will add a couple of handfuls of salted cocktail peanuts to the pan.  I don't put my popcorn in a big bowl, I pop a full bowl with my popcorn popper (with oil) and spread it out between two jellyroll pans, then add peanuts before pouring on the caramel.  
I've made this twice in the past two weeks, and already have several requests for more.

text:
This is delish! I don't think I've ever left a review before for any recipe but had to, for this one. The only change I made was to keep the popcorn warm as suggested by others and I only baked it for 45mins. I have a convection oven and 45 mins was perfect. My initial stirring was tricky. However, when I would remove it at the 15 min mark, and mix again, it coated the less coated corn. After 3 times it was coated well. I will definitely be making this again.

text:
Turned out better than I thought it would while making it.  I don't use microwave popcorn so I popped my own about a 1/2 cup unpopped, it may have been too much because the caramel didn't cover it all completely (but it was still good)  My caramel didn't drizzel on it poured out in a big glob and was a little hard to stir in, but that might be because I used 1/2 cup of butter instead of 1.  It did have the consistency of cracker jacks when it was done, but that could be due to less butter, too much popcorn which I changed from the original recipe.  I use a glass 9x13 and a 14 x 11 wilton non stick pan.  I liked the non stick pan the best.  I will make this again!

None
text:
Last night I became a popcorn hero with this recipe.  I live in Guatemala and caramel popcorn almost doesn't exist.  I took a huge basket of the treat to a party last night and no one had ever tried it before.  I brought back a few crumbs, and requests for more.  This is easy, fast, and remarkably delicious.  I made it exactly as the recipe says, but made enough for 30 servings -- a really huge basket!!  One trick I learned here is to make the popcorn without salt or any kind of oil.  Save a clean paper bag from any fast food place. add half a cup of the raw kernels and fold down the top.  Toss it into the microwave for about 3 minutes and take out crisp, hot, healthy snacks.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

userID:
6061432
Display Name:
DeniseACM
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
24
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe for decades. I would say, keep your popcorn in the oven, in your pan, waiting for the candy. I put the popcorn in my largest roasting pan lined with foil. Don't worry about sticking. As long as it's hot, you can stir the candy on the popcorn. I do have a couple tips. 1...If you have a spoontula, use it. It's soft and won't scrape foil, yet flat on end so you get all the candy while stirring. 2...Air popped is best. Plus I dump it in paper grocery bag and shake the biggest popcorn to the top. 3...1 qt is equal to 4 cups when measuring popcorn. 4...Whether you like your caramel corn light or dark, you can adjust what kind of corn syrup to use. Also light or dark brown sugar. 5... Don't worry about coating ALL the popcorn with the first pour. By the time it gets stirred 3 times in the oven, it should be all coated. :) 6... Feel free to add peanuts or any favorite nut. Mine is pecans. Just lay them on top of waiting popcorn before you add the candy. They will eventually stir in throughout. 7... When finished baking, work quickly and dump onto sheet of foil. No greasing required. . ... Love this recipe! Few ingredients and few dishes!
Review:

5

text:
We make this recipe, then make a batch of cheese popcorn and then mix them to make our own Chicago blend.  It's super easy.  I use a large non-stick roasting pan, heat the oven with the pan in it.  Pop the popcorn and toss it in the pan in the oven while I make the caramel.  If the popcorn is hot and the pan is hot the caramel will spread quite easily.

text:
Here is how I made it:  pop the popcorn in wok.  Transfer the popcorn in the pan and keep warm in oven.  I melt 1/2 cup of butter, 1/2 corn syrup, 1 cup Splenda brown sugar blend in the wok, then finish the recipe with the other ingredients and bake as directed.  Turned out great.  

I also tried to sub all sugar with Truiva but the popcorn didn't get crunchy when it cooled down.  

Thank you for the recipe.

text:
I made half the recipe, and cut the butter in half again, as several raters did.  So, I ended up using 1/4 cup butter.  Everything was peachy keen till I added the vanilla.  When you boil sugar for 4 minutes, it's very hot.  After removing from the flame, I added the baking soda and vanilla, and in 1 second's time, the vanilla sputtered and spat like an angry cat.  And burned.  I dressed the popped corn anyway, and baked it at 200 degrees, as another rater suggested.  Stirred it every commercial break during the football game.  Baked only 45 min, as another rater suggested.  Nice and crispy!  A little too burned for complete pleasure, but enjoyed just the same.  Next time, no vanilla.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Seriously Outstanding!! Follow the instructions exactly.  Notes:  1)  5 quarts of popcorn = 20 cups of popped corn.  2) I baked mine in a large stainless roasted pan and oiled the pan with canola spray first so the popcorn did not stick.  Next time I will buy disposable foil roasting pans from the dollar store (cleaner).  Most users are suggesting to use 1/2 cup of butter instead of 1 cup;  I tried this with both 1/2 cup and 1 cup and found 1 cup is easy because the mixture is thinner and easier to stir the popcorn -- but both work fine and taste amazing!  3) When you remove from oven after 1 hour stir the popcorn a few times while it is cooling to break up all the clusters.  4)  Store in ziplock bags if you are eating it yourself, but if you are giving it as gifts you can place a bunch in medium sized plastic gift bags (sold at Walmart) or buy some cute large tins from the dollar stre.  LOVE this recipe - definitely a winner for holiday gifts and you should definitely make this!! Thanks for posting and Happy Healthy Holidays!!

text:
Fantastic recipe!   I did have my pan (with the popcorn in it) in the oven while I was making the caramel.  I will say that it is super important to "boil" your caramel on medium/low heat.  As soon as it started to boil I put my timer on for 4 minutes and it came out perfectly.  I used my roaster insert to bake the the popcorn in the oven.  Rather than stirring every 15 minutes as the recipe called for, I stirred about every 5.  I had no trouble with clumps and it was a big hit in our house.  I plan on putting it in my holiday baskets next year.

text:
I AM PLEASANTLY SURPRISED AT HOW FORGIVING THIS RECIPE IS! IT WAS RAINING OUT, AND I HAD PROMISED MY GRAND KIDS THAT WE WOULD MAKE CARAMEL CORN WHEN THE RAIN CAME. SEEING AS THEY ARE NOT ONE'S TO FORGET, I SOON REALIZED THAT "IMPROVISE" WAS GOING TO BE AN UNDERSTATEMENT. THE ONLY POPCORN I HAD ON HAND WAS POP SECRET~ MICROWAVE (EXTRA BUTTER NO LESS). WE POPPED 3 BAGS TOTAL, MADE THE REST OF THE RECIPE EXACTLY AS WRITTEN, BUT MADE THE FOLLOWING CHANGES, INSTEAD OF DRIZZLING THE CARAMEL OVER THE POPCORN, WE PUT EVERYTHING INTO A VERY LARGE TUPPERWARE CONTAINER, AND USED A LARGE WOODEN SPOON TO COMPLETELY COAT THE POPCORN BEFORE BAKING. WE ALSO BAKED THE COATED POPCORN FOR ONLY 30 MINUTES INSTEAD OF THE FULL HOUR. IT WAS BEYOND PERFECT.MY HUSBAND ATE AN ENTIRE BOWL OF IT BEFORE IT WAS EVEN BAKED.  IT WILL BE A FAMILY TRADITION FROM NOW ON. WONDERFUL:)

text:
Love this recipe. You will definitely be better off if you use warm popcorn and mix it in a large stockpot (brown paper bag is ok too, but you have more control over the distribution of the caramel if you use a stockpot and stir it). I have made it several times and now, always comes out great. I add salted peanuts before mixing it in the stockpot right before the last "stir".

text:
This was a great recipe. Turned out crisp and flavorful. I used the tip from another reviewer and used a grocery bag to coat the popcorn. MUCH easier than stirring. You lose a little of the caramel but it works great because it doesn't pour in a trickle, but rather blobs. So I poured a 1/3, shake, 1/3, shake, etc.  Coated the pop corn great and easy cleanup just throw out the bag. I also only baked for 30 minutes and kept checking the corn after each 15 minute and found that 30 minutes was perfect for me.

userID:
17277603
Display Name:
Paul Sokolofsky
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3120699.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a few modifications for ease and taste.  I double the popcorn amount to 10 quarts.  I heat up the caramel in a large glass bowl in the microwave for 2:30, stir mixture, cook again for another 2:30, add baking soda, and stir.  I place all the popcorn into a standard size brown grocery bag.  Dump the hot caramel mix on top of the popcorn and shake the bag until popcorn is evenly covered.  Lay the wet popcorn onto baking pans in a very thin layer.  I cover the pans in tinfoil for easy clean up.  Stir every 15 for 1 hour at 250 degrees.  Store in an airtight container.  If stored for longer than a few days it becomes chewy.  Reheat at 250 degrees until warm and the crispness returns once its cools.  Enjoy!!!

userID:
6783617
Display Name:
tjeffress

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like others, I cut the butter in half and add a cup of roasted peanuts.  In place of 2 cups brown sugar, I use 1 cup white sugar and 1 cup brown sugar.  My wife likes the lighter flavor.  I mix the popcorn with the caramel in a large mixing bowl and then spread it onto the baking pan.  During the holidays, we mass-produce this making a full batch every 15 minutes and rotate it through our double oven.  (When people ask how was your weekend, it's fun to say, "I made 12 gallons of caramel popcorn.") 



Don't bother with non-stick cooking spray.  Yes, caramel will get all over your mixing spoons, and a little will stick to your baking pans, but sugar is very water soluble. A little hot water and soap cleans things right up.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
This recipe is delicious.  I make it every year in the fall for Halloween. I also make a Christmas version with 1/4 cup corn syrup and 1/4 molasses instead of the 1/2 cup corn syrup, and add some cinnamon to make a gingerbread version. 

The only time it has not turned out well, I got lazy and did not cook the caramel long enough.  It is key to make sure it boils for a good 4 minutes, or the caramel will come out grainy and mushy.  5 minutes probably wouldn't hurt it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous and easy to make.I can't stop eating it.
I got a little confused with the reviews discussing butter. I used one cup butter which equates to 2- 1/4 pound sticks.You also need to pop 1/2 cup + (1/2 of 1/4 cup) of corn. Comes out to 5 quarts. I'm going to find a cheep air popper for this only. I found taking my pans out of the oven and dumping into a large bowl, allowed me to break up the corn and mixes it well. The one hour works well.
Another thing, I kept the plain corn hot in the oven after removing the ol'maids. Drizzling the caramel on the warm corn was easy and it coated well. Thanks to all for the great reviews.

text:
I modified this by adding a cup of broken mini-pretzels and a half-cup of pecans to my halved recipe. DELICIOUS! The amount you add is arbitrary so have fun!

Why 4 stars?.. Length of time to make this. Had an emergency "What's for desert" last night and all signs pointed to Caramel Corn. I only left it in the oven for 15min since everyone wanted it right away. If you don't do the full-bake, it will still be delicious but the corn won't be crisp (adding the nuts and pretzels made up for this.).

Use only 1/2 cup of margarine. 1/2 cup of uncooked kernals=5 qrts.  Add pecans and peanuts. Bake at 200F for 40 mins. Stir every 2-3 mins when out of oven to prevent clumping. Be sure to spray pan first to prevent sticking.

I've made this 3 times now and it's amazing, the only thing I wish I knew the first time was to spread it on parchment paper after it comes out of the oven, then let it cool. text:
I followed the directions and used 1 tip.  I heated the popcorn up before adding the caramel. I was asked to add chocolate peanuts so I added chocolate and peanuts to one. The other I melted chocolate and stirred peanuts. Then I added them to the popcorn. You could probably add the peanuts to the caramel then add it and chocolate to the popcorn. One thing I recommend is to put the popcorn on wax paper to cool. Makes it much easier!

Great recipe but this is how I coat my corn: get the largest turkey baking bag they sell, and get on your garden gloves! Put corn in bag, pour syrup over, quickly twist bag shut, and turn over and over until coated with gloves on to prevent burns. Enjoy this delectable recipe!

city:

country:

text:
HOLY MOLY!!!! This stuff is ADDICTIVE!!!! My husband and I purchased a Nostalgia Electrics Popcorn maker and dispenser for the holidays. We were really wanting some carmel popcorn and we decided to just make our own! Found this recipe, and decided to give it a try because of all the wonderful reviews it had! Well we were not disappointed at all!!! We added chopped pecans to ours to make it our own! I sprayed the pans with non-stick cooking spray also. We had already had dinner that night and we were so full, but we could not stop eating it!!! My opinion, its better the next day after it has had a chance to cool completely and get that crunchy texture which I absolutely ADORE!!! This christmas I will be making tons of this popcorn and sending it to my family members!! Thank you to whoever shared this AWESOME, DELICIOUS recipe!!

text:
I ended up making two batches of this recipe today. I altered the serving size just a bit so I could use my hot air corn popper. Two batches of popcorn made 12 cups so I increased the recipe size. I did cut back on the butter by about half....left the remaining ingredients the same.  The second batch I made I threw in some pecans, almonds and peanuts for variety. I have to say its absolutely delicious. Other than cutting back on the butter, I wouldn't change a thing.  Oh....i didn't warm my popcorn before coating with the caramel and it seemed pretty good. Also, 250 degrees seemed to work well also. I did alter the pans from top to bottom rack every 15 minutes as I stirred so that may have helped some. Recommend for sure!!

country:
None
text:
When I make this I like to mix in 20 or so fun size twix candy bars n mix them through. My husband and especially my 4 yr old daughter love it. This is the exact recipe for the caramel I use when I make mine EXCEPT, I DON'T put ANY vanilla extract in it AT ALL!!!  The extract makes a huge difference in the taste I the caramel n makes it taste very cheap n store bought. Takes away from the wonderful homemade taste n makes it taste disgusting in my opinion. Best to make it both ways and decide go yourself, however if u make it exactly as the recipe calls for, just omit the vanilla extract, it tastes amazing!!!! I do not cut down on the butter. I make it exactly as written just leave out the extract n it is by far the best caramel popcorn I've ever tried. I would just suggest not drizzling with melted chocolate if u add candy bars. Makes it too rich. Leave out the extract and I would DEFINITELY give it 5 stars!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/494882.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One tip is that after you pop the corn, shake the bowl to help settle the few unpopped kernels.  Then carefully using your hands scoop up the popped corn into another bowl, trying not to disturb what has settled to the bottom.  I trash the uppopped and small hard popped corn along with the husks that have fallen to the bottom of the bowl.  I pop into an 8qt bowl then scoop into a 5qt, once that's filled I then pour it all back into the 8qt for mixing.  Also you can reuse the parchment paper several times.  I have been using this recipe for several years to rave reviews.  I have co-workers trying to convince me to package and sell it!

text:
this stuff is AMAZING!! I used 1 2/3 cup dark brown sugar and 1/3 white suga also 6 quarts or popcorn rather than 5. It was more than enough caramel to cover all the popcorn. 

I kept my popcorn warm in the oven (250) while making the caramel. I also added peanuts. Once the caramel was added in I only baked for 15 minutes. The result? A nice balance of crunch and chew. 

The only difference I'll make next time, and believe me there will be MANY next times with this recipe, is have someone else stir the caramel in. It killed my arm.

text:
Easy and great.... 

I put my popcorn in the lid of my roasting pan. I than measure out the pieces with my hands shaking out any unpopped kernels into the bottom (pam sprayed).
 
I than pour the caremel right ontop in the roasting pan and mix with a big wooden spoon. i put the lid in, shove it in a 200 degree oven for one hour (lid on) . every 15 minutes I take it out and give it a stir which makes makes it break up nicely. Nice and crunchy and shiney

I have tried the half cup and full cup of butter. both are good, although the full cup of butter does coat better.
Review:
Rating:
5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2354089.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make caramel popcorn every year to give as gifts as Christmas. This year my recipe was MIA, so I came here to find another. This one looked the same so I read a few reviews and gave it a try. I reduced the butter by about 1/4 cup and otherwise followed the directions. After 15 minutes in the oven, I threw the whole batch out. The caramel was crumbly and the popcorn just tasted like popcorn and brown sugar. Yuck! I read a few more reviews, then tried again using the full cup of butter and *name brand* brown sugar. I think the generic sugar I used the first time really screwed up how the first batch turned out. My second try was a success! Smooth caramel and so, so tasty! This is exactly the caramel popcorn that my family waits for every Christmas. A tip that might be helpful... I buy the disposable lasagna trays that come in a pack of 2 for about $3. I split the popcorn up between the two pans and drizzle the caramel over the top. The high sides of these pans makes mixing a cinch.

text:
I make this all the time and we just love it.  Dont bake it on a metal cookie sheet as this was the only time it burned, I use my stoneware cake pan which is deep enough to mix it in.  Also Only cook for half the time if you like the gooey caramel, otherwise the caramel perfectly coats the popcorn just like the store-bought stuff which is also good but I prefer the gooey :)

None
text:
This is very tasty. I do have one helpful suggestion though: spread the popped popcorn out onto your baking pans and then drizzle the Caramel sauce, mix, and bake. This will alleviate the mixing bowl step (when the popcorn and Caramel sauce can be mixed in the pan), and because it is spread out into two pans before mixing, the sauce is more evenly distributed. I did this the second time I made this and it was awesome-and with less clean-up!

text:
This recipe is absolute yum! The caramel is easy is to make and seemed fool-proof (which is amazing to me, as I have messed up caramel in the past)! I halved the recipe and am already regretting that I did that, which is sad bc the popcorn is still baking!! (plus, I keep stealing bits when I go to stir the popcorn).   I listened to past reviews and oiled the pot that I used for mixing (I had to use my largest pot bc I didn't have a bowl big enough). Also, I am baking the popcorn in a large non-stick pan with high sides, which is working nicely.    this is a must make.

userID:
4799319
Display Name:
Mysstryss
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

3
favoritesCount:
58
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7159663.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed others advice. Make sure you use a wooden spoon, metal will get too hot and sugar will melt plastic. I reduced butter to 1 stick (make sure you use real butter NOT margarine or spread). Took brown sugar down to 1 1/4 cup. I popped the popcorn in clarified butter (3/4 cup unpopped) on stove to give a richer nuttier flavor. Weed out the unpopped kernels and keep the popcorn warm in oven and spray whatever you are mixing popcorn/caramel in with non-stick cooking spray. I lined cookie sheets with parchment paper. Make sure you raise your oven racks a little higher and stir every 15 minutes or the caramel will get too dark and burnt taste. I only cooked for 45 minutes and cracked some sea salt over cooling popcorn to balance the sweet. Clean up was easy and the popcorn was delicious!

AWESOME recipe!!!   This was my very first time making caramel popcorn, and I was a bit intimidated at first with the whole process, but it turned out perfect! So perfect that I had to hide the batch while it cooled so that my family wouldn't eat it all!!   I followed the recipe as is and baked for only 45 mins (as recommended by a previous review) and the caramel coating came out nice and crispy! I will try using only 1/2 a cup of butter next time. For the popcorn, I used 1 1/2 cups uncooked popcorn, airpopped. My kitchen smelled like a day at the fair - SO YUMMY!!! Thanks so much for posting this recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Edited to add:  You CAN make this recipe for people watching their sugars.  I did a batch today with half brown sugar & half Splenda, and it came out very well -- but it hardens in less than HALF the time of sugar - so I burned the first pan.  About 20 minutes would have been right, with at least one stir.

I was very worried about putting baking soda in, and when it started to foam up over the side of the little saucepan it freaked me out.  But this was EXCELLENT.  The coating didn't soak into the popcorn the way that others have, and it baked up perfectly crispy.  I should have baked it a little less, as some of it got a 'burnt sugar' flavor beyond what I like.  But the remainder was absolutely perfect.  Next time, I'll try cutting the butter a bit as others suggested, and will limit my bake time to 45 min or so.  We did pan-popped popcorn, and popped just before boiling the coating, so the popcorn was all still warm when we poured the coating on -- poured it directly on in the pans and stirred with a silicone spatula, stirred while baking the same way, and didn't need to break it up much at all.

text:
I make this for my husband all the time and he says it like "gold" to him.  I always hated having to hang around the kitchen and stir every 15 minutes, so last night I experimented.  I turned the oven to 225, put the popcorn in for 30 minutes, stirred, and put it in for another 30 minutes, and then took it out.  It was perfect!  You do have to let it dry a tad bit more to get the crunch, but within 10 minutes after cooking, it tasted just like to original way of cooking it.  I give this to friends for Christmas, and they said they couldn't stop eating it!  Also, we use the popcorn that you cook over the stove (Orville Redenbacher) and it tastes fantastic- and way cheaper than getting it in a bag.  I cook the popcorn while the caramel is boiling for the 4 minutes so the popcorn is nice and hot when I mix the two.

text:
Oh my gawwwd!!!!! I don't know what I really expected but despite the rave reviews and my deep rooted affection for all things caramel, the final product knocked my socks off! I will never buy caramel corn again.....NEVER! These little crunchy clouds of caramelized goodness have me saying to heck with the butter, I'll just have to rock my hip hop abs with a caramel corn butt!    I started with half cup butter, but at boiling time it looked a wee bit too thick so I added the second stick.   Seriously mix, boil, pour, dry. It's that simple, and even without nonstick spray (I missed a pan)it cleans up with a quick set in some hot water. I'm a pigpen cook (flour on the cabinet doors and in my hair every time I prep a pan)....my kitchen is still clean!  This is now and probably forever my favorite recipe. Thank you, thank you, thank you.

text:
I've made this popcorn twice now, and it is very addicting! I've really only made one adjustment - the first time I made it I began baking as directed and the popcorn started getting really dry, especially after the 45 minute stir. The second time I made it I followed the review to up the temp to 300 degrees and bake for 20 minutes (stirring half-way) and that worked great! Enjoy!

text:
This is a classic recipe. I too have made a similar version for years and it always turns out yummy. (Our dogs go nuts for it too!) Like some other reviewers, i also cut the amount of butter in half and it still rocks. Sometimes i add a little almond extract or cinnamon oil in addition to the vanilla to mix things up a bit. Habanero or cayenne is also good mixed in with the caramel (before mixing with the popcorn) for adventurous fellow chile heads!

text:
This recipe is the best!  I've been making this recipe for many years and everyone who taste it want the recipe!  I also add whatever nuts I have on hand, i.e., cashews.  Don't be intimidated to try it, as it's so easy!  To make clean-up a breeze, spray Pam on the baking sheets and the utensils used to mix the popcorn.  Because it goes so fast, I've been "1 1/2x' ing" the recipe.  Storing it in airtight canisters keeps it fresher longer.

text:
I used to make a similar recipe but as I couldn't find it and after reading the rave reviews on this, I thought I'd make some for coworkers. I am arbitrarily giving this 3* as I don't know how it really should come out.  I don't usually make microwave popcorn, but knew it would be easier. I tried to find natural ~ old fashioned microwave popcorn as another reviewer recommended,but all I found were flavored ones. So, I decided I would pop my own.  But, how much?  Somewhere, a reader said 2 cups kernels.  WRONG! I had my roaster pan plus 2 lasagna pans full, but not enough syrup.  After wasting a couple of hours & $ on ingredients, I ended up re wrapping the holiday bowls  for next year. I'm really disappointed as I now do not have time to start w/ something else.  Next time, microwave!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This came out excellent.  Very easy to make just be sure to have everything laid out in advance.  I used a large roasting pan to hold the popcorn and bake it in the oven. The higher sides of the roasting pan it made stirring it easier.  

For the popcorn I used a microwave oven popcorn popper.  The one we have takes 1/2 popcorn kernels and 2 minutes 20 seconds to pop up a batch.  It took two batches to make enough popcorn for the recipe.  This was less expensive than using plain microwave popcorn and easier than popping it on the stove.

There was just the right amount of caramel to cover all of the popcorn well.  This will definitely become a regular at our house.

One Word--Amazing!  If I could rate it more, I would.  I made this as a snack to eat during my son's baseball games and everyone loved it.  It was super easy to make.  We kept licking the spoons and spatulas once we made up a pan.  I used air-popped popcorn by Orville Redenbacher and it turned out very well.  I also used light brown suger and light corn syrup, since the recipe didn't specify.  I think it just made the color lighter.  This is one recipe I will be making for years for many different occassions.  

Make this and I promise you will not be disappointed.  Simply wonderful!

text:
My guests (teenagers) and I LOVED this popcorn!  I only used 1/2c. butter and it was fine.  We were too impatient to cook it the whole hour so only did about 35 mins and it was still crunchy and perfect!  Not sure why you'd need to bake it so long.  However, if you make it as written it makes a HUGE mess in your kitchen.  One pot, a huge bowl, and at least two cookie sheets covered in sticky caramel mess that has to be scrubbed off.  Not fun!  I will make this again, but will try the paper bag method suggested by another viewer or use a disposable roasting pan!  Thank you!

text:
This is my first time making caramel popcorn. I just finished baking my last batch, whew! It's quite a process but well worth it and your family or friends will love it. (I hope) I tried using only 1/2 cup butter and the caramel was really thick and hard to mix with the popcorn. Using 1 cup butter is easier to mix with, the appearance is better and you can make more. Thanks!

text:
This recipes yields perfect caramel popcorn every time... I love it! I've made batches with and without nuts, and regardless of the addition of nuts it turns out wonderfully. Don't be concerned if you can't get the caramel to coat the popcorn evenly before you put it in the oven. The 15 minute interval stirs while in the oven helps remedy any unevenness in regards to the coating. Makes a wonderful snack and gift, thanks for the recipe!

text:
Tasty recipe and easy to make. However, I did not find that there was enough sauce for the 5 quarts of popcorn, which I carefully measured.

I made mine in two pans. Since there was not enough room for both pans on the same rack, I used two racks. The pans were staggered with very little overlap. The pan on the bottom rack burned. Next time I will try to find a larger pan that can fit all the popcorn and bake it all on the same rack.

I added some pecans, but I think peanuts would be better.

userID:

Display Name:
LIANA

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/40792.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I got a recipe very similar to this from the Karo syrup website. I doubled what they listed for the caramel mixture, and did not add the 3cups nuts as they suggested. The main differences I see, are that I used a full cup of Karo syrup & a full teaspoon of baking soda.  This was plenty for the popcorn I got from 1cup unpopped corn (didn't measure the amount). It filled a foil turkey roaster, heaping a bit. I cooked in on 300deg for 45m, stirring every 12-15min so it didn't burn. There was plenty of caramel for the popcorn. I would highly recommend keeping the popcorn warm while cooking the syrup, it prevents the corn from wilting better. I gave this 4 stars cause I think the extra syrup & baking soda are important.

text:
delicious...kids loved it, husband ate so much he was ill...note...i found it tricky with the boiling for 4 mins..my copper bottom pots cook faster and by 3 mins it smelled a bit burnt, so i took it off, put in the soda  and vanilla, and poured it on anyway,. it tasted burnt...so i made a new batch, only let it boil unstirred 2 mins, then added vanilla, then soda and it worked perfect...i learned that if it smells a bit burnt you can taste that. so don't waste the popcorn, start over....overall fairly easy and delicious...

text:
This is a great recipe. I use an air popper to pop the corn. I found it is much better if I carefully remove the uncooked seeds before adding the caramel sauce. Otherwise, they stick to the popped kernels. The end result is definitely better than any gourmet carmel corn I've had.

Dec/2010 try using 1/2 cup butter, lots of reviews and they cant tell the difference.  foiled the cookie sheet and sprayed it with Pam.  Baked it for 30 mins. turning twice. It was gone in one night.  My husband went into auto-feed and devoured it, I also helped but of course just a little!!!  I will make this on a regular basis. 
Thanks again, Michele, cambridge, ontario
update: used 2 bags micro popcorn. Used large roasting pan to mix and bake. sprayed pan with cooking spray.  Added pecans!!!!

text:
This was soooo easy.  I didn't even bake it and it came out perfect.  I used 1 bag of microwave popcorn and 1/2 of all the other ingredients to make several servings for my kid's snack.  I boiled the caramel as stated then poured it over the popcorn, stirred well and waited 10 min. for it to cool.  Voila.  It was done and my kids ate it up.  I don't know what baking it does, but it wasn't necessary in my opinion.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I scaled it to 5 servings which made it nice for a night snack. I airpopped the kernels and placed the popcorn in a big bowl that was lightly sprayed with olive oil cooking spray. This made it easier to stir. I only had coconut extract so I used that instead of vanilla and I found no difference in taste. I followed RENEE BURTON's advice and used a brown bag in the microwave, yet i only did it 3 times and some pieces were burnt. The popcorn had a buttery coat on it so next time I will not use as much. Overall very tasty and easy to clean up!
